1.content:
Living on the wrong side of the tracks in a city like Daven's Port would put a damper on most people's spirits.

Crammed into a tiny house with a pregnant mother and a flippantly irresponsible sister, scraping by from paycheck to paycheck was no way to live. But that never stopped Piper Black from doing pretty much whatever she wanted before, and it certainly didn't look to be stopping her anytime soon.

Piper is a native Daven's Porter with a big mouth and a penchant for getting into trouble. She has shoulder length black hair, olive-colored skin, and stands a bit taller than most of the boys in her graduating class at 5'10". She's quite busty, her breadth of breasts fed by her love of pizza and a natural inclination against running.

She lives with her mother, Harper, and her shitty older sister Parker in a little crackerbox about half an hour from the ocean. It's not a luxurious life, but it could have always been worse.

After all, she used to be fat.

Now she's about to begin her next adventure in Daven's Port, and this one might be her biggest one yet...

How does this adventure start?

11.content:
The Black house is never a peaceful one.

The thought of three equally outspoken, sometimes overbearing women stuck in such close quarters with one another would be enough to make weaker folks cringe. Add in one recent divorce, a parting gift pregnancy, live paycheck to paycheck for a few months with a dash of butting heads with Mom, sprinkle in a pinch of sister who doesn't do shit, bake for eighteen years, and you've got Piper Black's whole life in a nutshell.

They'd never been well off. And honestly, they'd never really gotten along. Piper's immediate family of three was loud enough for most people's reunions. There was always a lot to fight about, and that was before the pregnancy. Once Dad left and Parker started butting heads with Mom all the time, things only got worse.

But for few hours, just little cracks, there were moments of respite.

Piper just laid there, in her room. The lights were still off, and the soft blue light of the morning was trickling in through her blinds. She was still caught somewhere between truly sleeping and just cat napping. Those few, precious minutes before the house came to life were a rare occasion. It was the only time when there wasn't a TV blaring or a speaker-rattling the floorboards. When Mom and Parker weren't at each other's throats. When the whole house was quiet.

It was nice.

Piper laid there in her bed. Her long black hair was strewn about her pillows. Her brown eyes hung heavily, the taste of sleep still fresh on her tongue. The only sound in her room was the fan going, whirring, humming as the blades went round and around. Piper had been staring at the fan for a while now, trying to use it to go back to sleep. It hadn't worked yet, but she could feel her eyelids drooping a bit more and more with every passing moment.

Better get some sleep now, she told herself as she shut her eyes, you know you won't get any once everyone's up...

So she snuggled up, extra tight, beneath the covers. It was summer, but she still had on her thick blanket. Maybe that was part of the problem? Why she hadn't been sleeping well lately. Too hot? Maybe it was time to break out that old thinner one. Ugh, but that one was so scratchy...

Maybe she could just start sleeping naked?

Parker did it, most of the time.

Could sleeping naked really make that much more of a difference? Wouldn't her body itch? Like, rubbing against the sheet and all that. Her nips pressing up against the pillow? (You know she was a hugger, and she liked to sleep on her stomach!) But still, it had to beat waking up all sweaty...

Maybe that was her answer? If she just took off her clothes, she could get a couple more minutes of sleep. Just a couple more.

Piper inched her fingers down to the hem of her t-shirt, and slowly tugged it off. Her breasts splayed out gratefully, itching with freedom as she scratched them jovially. God that felt great. But since when was that shirt too tight?

They can't possibly be getting even bigger, can they? Piper rolled her eyes as she cupped and jiggled and jostled her olive colored mammaries, That's the last thing I need right now. New bras.

Laying there, her hands on her chest, Piper slowly began to drift off. Her thoughts became hazy, and the sound of the fan began to lull her back towards Nod. Her chest rose and fell, slowly but surely becoming slow and sure. Her mouth opened oh-so-slightly, and a small-half snore escaped her. Her brown eyes inched, inched, inched closed until finally, the whole room was black. She felt her eyes roll into the back of her head as she began to drift off. Slowly, slowly she fell and fell until—

WAH WAH WAH WAH...


Her alarm went off.

"Dammit Piper!" she heard her sister cuss through the cheap thin walls, "I was almost asleep!"

"God I'm getting it!" Piper hollered back, "Don't get your petri dish panties in a wad, Parker, it's a biohazard!"

Yup, welcome to life in the Black house.

"Piper I swear to GOD if you don't shut that thing off I'm going to sit on you and let your eyeballs pop out of your skull!" she heard her mom roar from all the way down the hall, "Turn. It. Off!"

And that's just the beginning of a day in the life of Piper Black...

111.content:
You know, getting dressed in the morning with a room as messy as Piper’s wasn’t exactly easy to do.

Everything was kinda... all over the place. Some in part due to Piper’s “eclectic” style of decorating, and the other parts a mixture of her own unwillingness and seeming inability to clean her room anything farther than half-way. It was a defect on the Black family gene if anyone else’s room was any indication, rest assured. But they managed to get by just fine.

Piper threw on one of her band t-shirts. 21 Pilots might be a little overplayed, but damn if they couldn’t make a good t-shirt. The logo looked great spread across her chest--she’d bought it about a size too big to make sure that the girls had enough room to breathe; just big enough to give her chest some room, but not so big as to make her look dumpy. Standing at the mirror above her desk, Piper combed her long black hair and pulling them into two twin ponytails, going for something between “quirky” “flirty” and “I didn’t feel like actually doing my hair today” before jumping into a pair of skinny jeans that (while she would never admit it) seemed a lot more skinny as of late than she cared to remember.

“Hey Ma, I’m headed out!” Piper called back into the little hobbit hole, “If you need me, text me okay?”

”Noo, why would your heavily pregnant mother need you for anything?” she could practically hear her beached mother roll her eyes as she hollered from the master bedroom, ”At least make sure you stop by D’s on your way home! Your sister ate all the donuts!”

“Kay, love you!” Piper called out without looking back, letting the screen door slam as she hurried down the rickety wooden porch towards the sweet salty smell of freedom...

***


Daven’s Port, rather the area of Daven’s Port that surrounded her depressingly impoverished neighborhood, had always been Piper’s favorite escape from her troubled home life. Even before the falling out between her folks, she had always been a professional street rat. Back when she was still in high school (read: literally a month ago), she would skip classes to cause all kinds of trouble with various other truants. Smashing bottles in alleyways, hooking up with dudes who she thought were her age, hooking up with other dudes who definitely weren’t her age, a little loitering... you know, a regular adolescence.

Among the places she wasn’t still banned for her behavior during her young, impressionable days, Piper was welcomed almost everywhere else. She had a vast repertoire amongst the locals. Shopkeepers, street vendors, even some cops knew Piper. Whatever the trade off, it was a lot better than home most days.

Which was why she was so very eager to show Dakota Johnson, a newbie to the good old DP, all the ins and outs of the city that she so very much loved to call home.

Oh, and Zack was there.

Because, you know, it’s Zack. And he tended to go most places where two pretty girls went and it wasn’t a school night.

“Don’t tell me that they don’t have donuts in Texas, Dee.” Piper guffawed, “Or do they have them, but you have to pronounce them with an accent or something?”

Dakota Johnson was a twiggy little thing who had just moved in a few streets over. On the “good” side of their neighborhood. Typical nuclear family--Breadwinner Dad, Stay-At-Home Mom, Annoying Little Brother, and one Why-Did-We-Move-Here? Daughter. Her life was about as Basic as they came; it could have easily been the next premise of one of those godawful teen dramas (on ABC, of course). Which was where Piper had been making an effort to step in and try to make her life a bit more interesting than staying at home listening to... country music. Or whatever someone did when they missed Texas.

“Well yeah, it’s just... you know...” Dakota held up her Homer Simpson Special, “I don’t think I’ve ever seen a donut this... big.”

Dakota was a pretty small girl. Narrow in the waist, narrow in the chest, big in the butt. She had long brown hair liked to wear tank tops and short shorts. The real girl next door archetype. But the girl was right--donuts like the Homer Simpson Special didn’t exist anywhere else. Only in Daven’s Port, circa D’s Donuts!

...And, Piper supposed, the FOX Network, for licensing purposes.

“What, they aren’t all Ten Gallon Hat sized?” Zack offered from Dakota’s end of the table, “I thought everything was bigger in Texas?”

Dakota groaned, and Piper punched him in the arm.

Zack was younger than either of them. He was only a junior in high school (an aspiring senior after the Summer, he was quick to remind her!) and was something of an old friend of Piper’s. Back when Zack’s folks made the split (well before Piper’s) Piper had been quick to come to his aide and keep him from becoming one of the insedit troublemakers that wandered around the streets because their parents didn’t love them. Now that Piper was a child of divorce, he had been just as quick to ensure the same. He was always there for her, and as much as his mom hated her, there was always a place for her to crash if she needed it.

Still, that didn’t mean he was funny.

Zack was a shorter guy with sandy blonde hair that hung down to his eyebrows. As he’d been told most of his life, he was very punchable.

Most times, Piper agreed.

“Shut up, Zack.” Piper groaned, “You’ll scare away our new tourist.”

They’d been hanging out with Dakota for the better part of two weeks now. Showing her the ropes, easing her out of that monument to normality they called a two-story house. Maybe mooching off her folks a little. But this was the first time they’d ever gotten her to go out to eat.

“So this is what you guys do for fun?” Dakota giggled, “Eat donuts and beat up Zack?”

“Mostly.” Piper said with a smile, punching Zack again from across the table, “But sometimes we go to the beach.”

“Sometimes she kicks me.” Zack grumbled before Piper kicked him swiftly underneath the table, “GODDAMMIT.”

So far, it had been pretty fun! Piper never really pegged Dakota as someone she would have thought she could get along with. With her long brown hair and her penchant for preppy, basic thoughts. But she and Dakota had become fast friends, ever since Dakota let her hide out in her backyard while she hid from some less-than-scrupulous Russian gentlemen. Despite what her mother thought about her.

“Okay, so...” Dakota led, taking a bite out of her donut, “Which of the two things left to do in Daven’s Port are we gonna do today? Since, you know, we’ve kinda already got donuts...”

“Actually...” Piper said with a smile...

1112.content:
"The movie theater? Really?" Dakota asked, skeptically.

         "What? Are you some kind of weirdo who doesn't like movies?" Piper teased.

         "No it's not that." Dakota stiffled a small giggle. "It's just, I thought you were showing me what Daven's Port has to offer. You know we have Movie theaters in Texas, right?"

         "Ah, but you don't have the Rio." Piper said triumphantly.

         "...The Rio?" Dakota asked, a little intrigued.

         "Check it out. The Rio was first opened like, 80 years agao, when movies were like, new." Piper explained. "But a few years ago, this cool chick bugged the city to restore it, and they let her."

         "Plus, it's a great place to hang out in the summer when you don't have an AC." Zack added.

         "Wait, what?" Dakota asked, the idea that anyone couldn't afford an AC was alien to her.

         "Just come on!" Piper said, grabbing Dakota's wrist and dragging her out of the donut shop, and off to the movies. They all piled into Zack's cheap, used van he had acquired from a gentleman of questionable means. It took them a few tries to get the engine to turn over, but it finally did.

         The first thing that caught Dakota's attention about the Rio was the sing. The sign was in about ten thousand little lightbulbs, red and green and blue spelling out the words "Rio". Dakota imagined it was much more impressive when the lights were actually on, and it was dark out, and not under the sweltering Carolina sun. Still..."This is...really neat." Dakota said, gazing up at it as they entered.

         "It's even neater once you meet the staff." Piper boasted, pointing at a bored looking employee at the concession stand/ticket booth as she continued to drag Dakota along for to meet her.

         She was tall, she must have been nearly 6 foot, and definitely was over 6 feet if you counted the poofy black hair that must have been kept up by a can of hair spray every morning. 'Someone should tell this woman the 80s ended' Dakota thought wryly to herself. She also had, *ahem*, generously endowments, aided along by a thick frame, and olive skin and strikingly handsome features. Dakota looked at the ticket taker, then back at Piper, then back at the ticket taker.

         "Are you two related?" Dakota asked, "Is that why you're so excited for me to meet the staff?"

         "Hahaha, your new friend is funny, Piper." The manager said, in a nasally Brooklyn accent. It was hard to tell if she was being sarcastic or overly enthusiastic. "What's her name?"

         "This is Dakota, she just moved here from Texas. And NO Dakota, we're not related. Why would you even think that?"

         Dakota looked back and forth between the two taller women's chests before saying "...no reason."

         "My name's Sam, Sam Palermo." She offered Dakota a handshake. She shook hands like a dude. She tilted her head at Piper. "You're all here for the 'Saturday Special'?"

         "What's the 'Saturday Special?'" Dakota asked. Piper had been waiting to share this surprise with her.

         "For twenty bucks, Sam here will let you watch movies in theater three all day. Eat all the popcorn and soda you can stomach as well!"

         "It's PERFECT for beating the heat on days like today." Zack said, sounding like this place was an oasis in a desert.

         Dakota was starting to see the appeal of this place. "All day? I dunno, what movies are out this week?" Dakota asked.

         "Oh, Saturday Special at the Rio are managers pick. We just play whatever I feel like playing all day."

         "And what's that?" Dakota asked.

         "Eh...I dunno, you guys like Rifftrax?"

         "...What's Rifftracks?" Dakota asked.

         "Only the best thing ever." Zack explained.

         "Have you ever seen Mystery Science theater?" Piper asked Dakota. Dakota just shook her head

         "You're culturally deprived. They're these guys on the internet. They make bad movies into good ones."

         "You can play something like that in a movie theater?" Dakota said, her mind expanding. I mean, she knew literally they could. But 'stuff from the internet' and 'movie theater' never went together in her mind until now. It was like apple and cheddar.

         "Girl, I'm like a DJ up in here on Saturdays. We can play WHATEVAH the hell I want, and I DO take requests. Let me get you three some popcorn." Sam said, taking out three large tubs.

***

         After several hours of Rifftrax, Steve McQueen Movies, as well as some very brief showings of Godzilla vs. Bambi, and Mickey Mouse goes to Vietnam, the trio felt like they had consumed enough movies, and popcorn, to last them a lifetime, or at least until next week. So they got themselves moving finally, waved to Sam on the way out, and hauled their bloated, sluggish bodies out to the van. By now, the afternoon sun was starting to sink below the horizon, tinging everything slightly orange. As they stepped out, Sam turned on the lights, and Dakota got to see the sign of the Rio lit up and pulsating.

         But when they got to the van, no matter how many times Zack cranked the ignition, the van only gave them a buzzing sound like angry bees. Zack dropped his head down on the steering wheel, defeated.

         "I told you to get this shit fixed." Piper complained.

         "With what money?" Zack pointed out. "Besides, I don't think it's broken, I think we just need someone to give us a jump. The battery has been acting up lately. Let's just call someone for help."

         "Uh...speaking of battery troubles...my cell phone died while we were in there all day." Dakota said, holding up her iPhone, which only gave a red battery symbol before turning off. Piper checked hers.

         "Shit...Mine too."

         "And mine has no service, because I couldn't pay the bill this month." Zack added.

         "...I guess we could go inside an ask for help." Piper said, shrugging and heading back into the theater. Zack and Dakota followed, it wasn't like they had anything better to do.

***
         "Heeeeey, Piper. You're back already. This is why you're my favorite customer." Sam teased, seeing her back inside.

         "Ugh...Zack's shitty ass van broke down in your parking lot. Can we use your phone?"

         "We think the battery is just dead. We just need a jump." Zack quickly added. She was scared Sam would call a tow truck, and he'd lose his Van, and have to pay for a tow.

         "It's not the battery Zack. Your van is a peice of shit." Piper said. Sam eyed the two of them up and down.

         "...Tell you what. I'll do you one better. Hold on a minute." Sam held up a finger in front of Piper's staff, and then turned towards the other woman working at the stand, helping someone at the far end with some nachos. Sam yelled like, uncomfortably loud at her. "Hey, Tiffany! I'm clocking out early. See you tommorah!"

         "...Are you sure you're not related?" Dakota asked.

         "If you keep making jokes like you're Zack, I will punch you like you're Zack." Piper shot back.

***
         They didn't know what Sam had planned, but she marched right outside, up to Zack's van, opened up the hood, and without hesitation started shoving her hand deep into the bowels of the ancient, grease smeared engine. After about only 10 minutes, Sam had her diagnosis ready.

         "It's not just the battery, it's the alternator. That's why the battery keeps on dying. And christ, when was the last time you changed the frikken' oil on this thing?"

         "Nineteen...seventy three?" Zack said, optimistically.

         "I'm gonna hook you up with a new alternator and battery tonight, but the oil change you gotta do yourself."

         "That's really generous of you." Dakota pointed out. "But there's no way there's a mechanic with the parts we need open on this hour on a Saturday."

         "Sure there is." Sam said, pointing her thumb at herself. "You're looking at her right here.

***

         Sam led them downstairs into the surprisingly vast basement of the Rio. "Back when films were put on...you know, Film, the Rio had to actually store cases and cases of celluloid reels down here. That's what caused it to go out of business, those things go up like gasoline, and there was a fire. Only now, I can store like a thousand movies on a harddrive, so I got all this space to use." She explained, guiding them threw row after row of stacked car batteries and autoparts, still in their boxes.

         "That explains the space. That still doesn't explain why, the basement of your movie theater is full of car batteries." Zack pointed out.

         "Oh well...half the money for the restoration was put up by the city and fundraising, and the other half by my family so...I gotta store batteries and such for them with the spare space."

         "And they're not going to be mad that you just let us have some for free?" Dakota asked.

         "Oh...we can't sell any of these. They're erm...used." Sam explained, awkwardly. "Look, you guys do me a favor and not tell anybody about this?"

         Dakota looked nervous, but this wasn't nearly the shadiest operation Piper had ever been around. "You got it Sam. Anybody talks, they'll have to answer to me." Piper teased. Half-Teased. She was kind of teasing.

         "Thanks Pipes, you're a real Peach...So...where you guys off to after this?"

"We're going to a bonfire party, wanna come?"

Here the older, taller, bigger-haired woman snorted with at least some dismissal. With her hands on her flaring hips, Sam looked her best customer and old friend up and down like she had just suggested they all go out to Chuck E. Cheese. It made Piper wince a bit; she didn't like feeling like a stupid kid. At least, not with Sam.

"What?" she asked defensively, "No good?"

"Uh-uh." Sam shook her head, her curly mane shifting, "You expect me to clock out and blow off my girls for a night out on the beach? You're gonna have to do better than that, Pipey."

There was a beat in the air as everyone just sort've shifted awkwardly on their feet. Piper looked down while Zack scratched the back of her head and Dakota avoided eye contact. When she put it that way, it was sort've hard to argue with Sam. Getting paid for a night of work did sound an awful lot better than the parties that they went to, at least most of the time.

"...there'll be beer?" Zack suggested, almost as an afterthought

"Now we're talkin'." A smile spread across the older woman's cheeks, "You didn't tell me it was gonna be that kinda party!"

Satisfied with their answer, Sam led the three teens out of the Rio's basement. She locked up behind her, leaving instructions with the remaining girls behind the various counters...

Maybe this party wouldn't suck after all, now that Sam got to come!

***


"So I'd just like to point out that nobody actually told me that there would be beer here." Dakota said meekly as she exited Zack's clanky rustbucket, "I-I've never drank before, guys..."

"Who invited the virgin?" Sam rolled her eyes from the front seat as she unbuckled

"Come on Dee, it'll be fun!" Piper encouraged her mousier friend with a rousing pat on the shoulder, "You're from Texas, right? They drink all the time down there, don't they? You can probably drink, like a ten gallon's hat in beer! Just don't worry about it—you've got me here, Zack, Sam—"

"I just met Sam."

"And you've probably already seen what a super cool chick she is!" Piper pat her friend's back again, "Just trust me, lay back, relax, and... try not to let anyone know how much of a square you are."

"That's what I do!"

"That's what Zack does."

The four descended on the sandy shores of Daven's Port. The Summer nights were hot and humid. The wet, heavy wind blowing up to the shore brought out the curls in Piper's hair as she lead her squad towards the tide. An amber glow colored the night like rust, Around a campfire, hastil constructed with driftwood and some seashells, a couple of native Porters awaited their arrival.

"Hey, it's Piper!" cried out Matt, the athletic surfer

"About damn time!" said Jay, the older hipster

"We were getting worried!" sweet, chubby Madi added

Yeah, this was the squad for the night. All in all, pretty good turnout! Usually these things were like, three, four people tops. But with Dakota included and Sam tagging along, plus Madi finally managing to get some free time, that meant that it wouldn't be a complete sausage-fest, and things didn't have to get weird when Piper had too much to drink!

Now what was in that cooler...

"Here, got you a cold one!" Jay tossed Piper a lukewarm Coors, giving Sam the up and down, "Who's your hot friend?"

"Zack Tyler, at your service." the younger boy smiled, Madi giggled

They had to pull up another chair (Zack had to walk all the way back to his van for it) but eventually things began to liven up and the night began to grow...

Eventually...

"My plan stopped at donuts. Lets loiter!"

As much of a lame plan as it was, nobody present seemed to mind. Especially since that was what the teenaged trio tended to do on any given day anyway. It was Summer in Daven's Port, and that meant that the city was more alive than ever. There were plenty of things to do and plenty of sights to see. New people coming in for the beach, shops and stands unveiling their newest tourist traps, and most importantly—food out the wazoo!

All across town, but especially in the pier and surrounding areas, local food vendors always went all out when Summer time came 'round. Ice cream trucks slashed their prices, cotton candy stands offered extra curly wigs for no extra charge, and grills could be heard sizzling all around. The salty air of the sea carried the smell of burgers, hot dogs, and even the sweet tangy scent of the Barbecue Hut. Everyone from Bongo's Burger Shack to House of Wings was crazy about peddling out free samples to wrangle in customers, and Piper was just the sort of girl to know how and where all the best spots in town were.

"Oh my god... so full..." Zack groaned as he leaned against the warm brick of an old building downtown, "I think I'm gonna spew..."

"No more..." Dakota cradled her full belly with one hand, the rim of her mouth sticky with cotton candy, "No more free samples..."

The afternoon sun hung low against the horizon as Piper led her feeble-kneed friends up the road and into downtown. Piper had led them on a crusade against common sense, and had insisted on hitting every stop in Daven's Port there was to hit. Starting with the sliders from the burger shack, then onto the big blue "ocean-side extravagance" cotton candy cones, then trying a free sample of every flavor at Carly's Creamery, and on and on and on. Around the time they'd stuffed down a few boneless bites, (in flavors ranging from honey-mustard to New York Mild) from House of Wings, Dakota and Zack were looking a little green around the gills. Their eating escapades had only been broken up by mild interference of kitschy tourist shops, but even Zack didn't mind going into Porter's Apparel so long as it meant he didn't have to eat another something for the next fifteen minutes.

"Oh come on, guys." Piper trudged forward, hardly worse for wear, "It's only a little further!"

Whereas Zack and Dakota had found it harder and harder to move with every approaching stand, shop, or stall, Piper seemed unencumbered by the bloated food-baby she was carrying around. The distended pooch of her gut looked uncomfortably full—for all that Zack and Dakota had eaten, Piper had easily led the charge. She was a little sweaty after having spent all day out in the sun, her long black hair starting to frizz, but that was about it. The fact that she wasn't doubled over in gastronomic agony was what worried her friends; she was just going to make them eat more!

Piper's insistence on taking advantage of every free food giveaway on the east side of town meant {i]every stop had to be made. They'd strategically made their way up and down the pier, through the beach, and into the city. She had promised that this would be the last one.

Steak n Shake was giving away free small milkshakes for another hour! Their all-day promotion was about to end, and Piper was going to be damned if she didn't get to wash her mighty meal down with a cool, refreshing strawberry milkshake!

"You've been saying that for hours." Zack moaned, "I'm friggin' beat..."

"It's been like fifteen minutes." Dakota cut her eyes in frustration at Zack, "But I'm with Zack... can't we just go home?"

"What? No way!" Piper piped, despite the fact that even she was struggling with the slight incline of the street, "I swear it's like... five more minutes, okay? Then we can be done."

Dakota and Zack rolled their eyes and kicked off of their respective stopping spots, making mental notes to never let Piper decide what they would be doing for the day ever again. They had literally been eating all day; starting with D's and ending with Steak n Shake. How many thousands of calories had Piper made them ingest for her own amusement?! At least with all this walking there was no worries about burning them all off.... hopefully.

And Piper was happy to lead them! Up the street, to the right, and then Steak n Shake was the first place on the right. Right next to that place that used to be the fancy Italian restaurant... what was it called? Papa's! It's right next to Papa's.

Hmm... come to think of it, was Papa's giving out free samples? She might have to check that out.

But as she continued onward, leading her reluctant friends behind her, something caught Piper's eye. Something that, thankfully for Zack and Dakota, wasn't food.

"What's that?" Zack asked, following Piper's line of sight.

It was an old shop, standalone from the rest of the buildings. It had its own little lot and a cute little canopy over the glass door. On first glance it looked to be closed. However, Piper could clearly make out a faint light inside. Maybe they just used dim bulbs? The sign on the door said open...

"Abida's Eclectics, huh?" Piper mused out loud...

"You're getting fat again." Parker said bluntly, poking Piper in her exposed belly pooch. She was right, she was getting fat, again. While everyone else in Daven's Port thought of Piper as a busty, shapely hourglass of a girl, Parker could never forget or let go of Piper's childhood. It was rough on all of them. Harper had to work full time to take care of them, and that left little time for cooking. Harper not infrequently resorted to picking up a Hot-N-Ready pizza from Little Ceasar's for $5 dollars and that would be dinner for the three of them. It didn't worry her that she'd split it between them.

There were other problems too. Harper used fatty, sugary foods to cheer the girls up whenever needed. When they couldn't pay the electric bill and the AC shut off one summer, Harper brought home a cheap tub of ice cream. And because food insecurity loomed, she always encouraged the girls to clean their plates. It also didn't help that, even when times were good, Harper had a terrible ignorance of nutrition. Coke was cheaper than water, and better in her mind, so they drank it like water in the Black house. Even when little Piper got a little exercise playing a little Pee-Wee basketball (it was almost free, and no equipment to bring), Harper thought it was a good idea to feed Piper soda and chocolate bars before hand to give her plenty of energy.

Of course, Harper wasn't the only one to blame. Parker grew up in this environment and never grew beyond pudgy, maybe it was her disposition, or maybe it was because she grew up with a little more stability before things fell completely apart, and knew better than Piper. And while Harper herself put on a few pounds after having the girls, it never got truly bad. But Piper was born into this, and took to it with gusto. She was matching Harper's meal sizes when she was in kindergarten. She loved to eat, and Harper saw nothing wrong with letting her, so she ate, and ate, and ate and...after a particularly fattening summer spent inside before the 6th grade, Piper weighed 250 pounds and was one of the fattest girls in her school. When her teacher called to inform Harper that Piper was too big to fit in the school's desk, it was like a bolt of lightning out of the blue to the overworked mother. She realized Piper didn't have a 'healthy' appetite. She was, in fact, totally unhealthy, so much so that she had trouble participating in gym class.

Harper blamed herself, but did the right thing: She got some books from the library, learned a thing or two about nutrition her parents never taught her, made an effort to cook meals at home more, and go for walks with the girls, even if she was totally exhausted. Making friends with Zack helped get her more a lot more active. A growth spurt along with puberty helped shift the rest of the weight, and by High School, Piper had gone from being the fattest tubster in class, to an hourglass shaped early bloomer that introduced countless boys to the concept of boobs.

It was a little weird to think that even this much taller, and even with her weight slipping, Piper still didn't weigh as much as she did when she was a kid. But here she was, sinking into the family couch, with her shirt riding up over her stomach, trying to watch TV and eat an ice cream sandwich as Parker poked her belly and started to bring out the old names. "Is Porky Piper coming back?" She sneered.

"Bitch fuck off, and grow out of middle school. It's pathetic." Piper growled, eating half the sandwich in one angry bite.

"Just because we're not in middle school, doesn't mean you can go and get fat, now."

"I can do whatever I want, Parker."

"If you're going to be fat again, can you at least do the truffle shuffle for me again?" Parker snickered. By now, Parker's antics had gotten Harper's attention. The poofy haired matriarch came over and suddenly yanked on Parker's ear. "Ow, ow, ow, ow! Mom, what the shit!?" She squealed in protest.

"You're going to act like you're in gradeschool, I'm going to treat you like you're in grade school. Leave your sister alone." Harper said in a clear, firm tone. She had brought another ice cream sandwich with her and handed it off to Piper. Without even thinking about it, she had grabbed one out of the freezer to console her daughter after that treatment. While Piper started on the next one, Harper rested a comforting hand on her shoulder. "Piper is an adult now, and she can eat whatever she wants."

Parker just rolled her eyes and turned back to the phone, while Piper smiled smuggly at her.

1113111.content:
As Piper stepped out of the shower, she caught a glimpse of herself in the mirror, seeing a chubby belly, and the signs that her second chin was returning. OK, she definitely wasn't getting any thinner. Maybe it was time to actually check out the damage. She gave her stomach a contemplative jiggle, and decided to quit being a bitch and hop on the scale.

She slid it out from it's nook behind the toilet. 'Damn,' she thought 'this thing has seen better days.' It had acquired through years of neglect, a coating of rust and grime. Always a little old and second hand (just like almost everything they owned), it actually relied on a dial spinning to show her weight. Piper hoped it still worked. She remembered how back in middle school, she used to get on this every Friday night, like clockwork. At first her mom had to make her, but then she delighted in the numbers going down nearly every week. When it first started, she didn't imagine how much she could lose. When her mom started their diet, she thought maybe she'd dent her weight by 10 or 15 pounds. Piper honestly had no idea how much she should weigh at the time. Eventually, she got down to 115 pounds at her lowest less than half of what she weighed. She literally shed an extra tween off herself, made of pure blubber. 115 was the low point right before puberty really got going and she received a new set of weights on her chest, and grew a few inches, but she never complained about that.

She looked down at the scale with trepidation, biting at her lips. She was gonna do this. She had no clothes on, so there was no cheating! Last time she saw a doctor, he'd told her she weighed 145 pounds, and she hand't changed too much in the years since then. Well, except in these last few weeks...

She stepped on the scale, and closed her eyes as it spun. She knew it would jump in a lot of weird directions and play with her emotions so she just closed her eyes, took a deep breath and counted to ten. She opened them and looked down. 195 pounds. At first she thought, or hoped, it was still spinning and waited a second for it to change, but it stayed there, unerringly.

Shit, 195. She'd gained like, 50 pounds in like 2 months. Was that possible? She knew it wasn't possible to lose weight that fast, that's for damn sure. She side-eyed herself in the mirror and slapped her gut. If she started now, maybe she could lose this by the end of the year, she thought.

'Fuck though...I really don't want to go on a diet again.' She thought. She imagined what would happen if she didn't though, and puffed out her cheeks in the mirror, arced her back and puffed out her stomach as much as she could for a few seconds. Then she let it going with a chuckle.

It was strange. While she should be upset, and most of her was terrified by this development, a small part of her was comforted by it. She was super self-conscious of her belly all the time now, and how it stuck out farther each and every day, but a piece of her...kind of missed it? It was like having an old friend back. Her belly had always been with her, made her feel better whenever she had some food to fill it with. There was a familiar weight to it that she hadn't realized she missed a little, like wearing her favorite pair of heavy boots. She stuck it out again, giving it an experimental rub. Her figure reminded her of her mothers, and for a moment she had a silly daydream that she was pregnant, and her belly would keep growing like this for 7 more months. It made her wonder how much her belly could fill up?

Only one way to find out. As she got dressed, a strange form of elation took over Piper, and suddenly, she couldn't give a fuck about her weight. She spent the whole evening seeing how much she could actually fit into her belly. She went out and spent her last dollar on snack and food, and retreated into the comfort of her own room. The results of her epic binge: And order of General Tso's chicken and rice, a jar of Pringles, a two liter of soda, a dozen donuts from D's, a jar of pickles she stole from the fridge, including the juice (she'd seen her mom do it and wanted to try), and six beers she stole from Parker. So when she staggered back into the bathroom at 2 AM, naked, she was a little drunk.

But oh, how her belly looked in the mirror. Piper got a real thrill out of that. It was kind of incredible seeing a real, dramatic effect on her body in such a short period of time. It was probably a trick of her mind, but she thought she looked actually fatter. She rubbed her gut. She could use it, she felt a little sick. Her hand reached to her navel and she stuck a finger inside it. It felt good. She stuck her stomach out again, and her hand drifted lower.

Tonight was fun. Piper couldn't think of a better way to end a great night like this then by going back to her room, masturbating, and falling asleep.

1113113.content:
In the weeks that followed, Piper would find herself without much to do.

For whatever reason, it was like Zack and Dakota didn't want to hang out with her anymore. Or at least, not as often as they used to. Dakota met a boy at one of their Under the Pier parties and had been stuck up his ass for the better part of ever since, and ever since Zack got a job at that ritzy hotel he never had time to do anything. Seriously, how hard or "exhausting" (or whatever he called it) was it to hit some keys on a keyboard and give people their room keys? That was a bunch of bull, and Piper could (and often did) call him out on it.

However, that didn't stop Piper from enjoying her Summer break.

Piper didn't need friends to have a good time. She was perfectly capable of spending her mornings, noons and nights alone. Or at least, as alone as you could get in a house with two other people. Especially people as loud as her mom and sister were. Piper had a TV in her room and an old Gamecube with, like, three functioning disks. There were Yoohoos in the fridge and snacks in the pantry. And on nights where Parker stayed out late or in the mornings when her hangovers were intense enough that she sequestered herself in her room, Piper had the whole couch to herself! Piper was plenty happy to plop down on the couch, unwrap an ice cream sandwich, and enjoy herself for once in her life.

Even if, as her friends responsibilities continued to outweigh their friendship with her, it just so happened to be every night.

It wasn't long before Piper's starter belly blossomed into a generous little pot that hung over the waistband of her jeans. Two little lovehandles pooched over the sides, her waist marred with angry red marks where the fabric suffocated her encroaching flab. Her rump was plump with the hours of sitting, grazing, and casual gaming that had filled her Summer, and her breasts had filled with the calories of every ice cream sandwich, burger, and hotdog that she'd sucked down. Piper was officially out of her old size, and had slipped into something a bit bigger. She did her best to keep the same style, but there was no disguising that Piper Black was getting fat.

At least, among other things, she wasn't being bombarded with jeers from every corner about her rising weight. As much as she didn't like to think about it, Piper could be rather sensitive when it came to her waistline; it was nice to know that someone was in her corner.

"You know, you don't have to go out if you don't want to." Piper's mother had told her as she struggled to pull up her jeans, "I mean, it's nice having at least one of my kids around to talk to. Plus, you know, I am making those mozzarella sticks you like."

"Ugh, I know..." Piper puffed, her chubby face red as she finally buttoned her pants, "I'm just so bored. All I do is lay around the house and eat."

"That's all your sister does too." Harper joked, taking the cheesy sticks out of the oven and placing them on the counter to cool

"Yeah, but she like goes out and parties." Piper self-consciously touched her growing middle, as if to stop it from jiggling like it had been when she was dressing herself, "I'm just gonna go hang out at the pier or something. Maybe see if Dakota or Zack want to hang out."

"Okay." Harper said, picking up a piping hot mozzarella stick, "But these'll be done in, like, ten minutes. You wanna at least wait until then?"

Piper's face grew flush as she sunk into herself.

"I know they're your faaaavorite." Harper dangled the hot fried cheese stick in front of her daughter's face...

***


One tray of cheese sticks later, Piper found herself out at the pier.

It hadn't changed much, despite her abstaining absence. The stalls were still there, most of the shops. Even a couple of the people, Piper recognized. Tourists didn't always leave after a week. Or maybe it was a return trip? Nobody would ever know.

However, the one thing that had changed was Piper. She was officially thirty pounds heavier since the last time she set foot on the damp wood and breathed in the salty air. As much as she liked to tell herself that it wasn't noticeable, she couldn't deny the pronounced jiggling when she walked, and not just in her titties. She kept tugging at the hem of her shirt, trying to make sure that none of her olive-colored chub was exposed. The walk had left her so tired... God, she was out of shape!

And tired....

And hungry...

Maybe she should just go home? It wasn't like anyone wanted to hang out anyway. Dakota was with what's-his-name and Zack had been put on second shift. The most interaction she was going to be getting with those two were infrequent texting and the odd social media messages. Above all things, Piper definitely didn't want to be the weird girl hanging out by herself at the pier...

"ICE CREAM, HALF PRICE HERE!" a vendor hollered, "BROKEN COOLING UNIT HERE, FOLKS—GET IT NOW BEFORE IT MELTS!"

Okay, maybe she could go after she got some ice cream.

A small crowd of people surfaced in wake of the caller's announcement. All ice cream was half off and it was a pretty warm afternoon, even for the Summer. Piper was one of about ten folks that had come over in order to take advantage of it—Piper had managed to score a Neapolitan triple for half price. Three bucks for three scoops was about the best thing that had happened to her all day!

Ugh, she knew she shouldn't. But this Summer had just been such a bummer. She makes a new friend, she gets dumped for a boy. Zack gets a job, dumps her for money. Then she'd put on a little weight, her sister had been such a bitch... ugh. Just ugh. Food always made her feel better—guess that was why she was such a fat kid in the first place...

"Piper?" a voice called out as she exited the crowd, "Hey, is that you?"

Piper stopped licking and took a look around. She knew that voice from somewhere—it sounded so familiar!

"Jesus, I'm behind you!"

Piper whipped around, careful not to topple her tower of dairy, only to be met with an old face! One that she thought she'd never see again...

11131132.content:
Summer Keegan.

Piper had to stop her jaw from falling onto her little tower of ice cream clutched in her chubby hand. She settled for leaving her eyes wide in shock as she recognized her long-forgotten bestie from the hard days of childhood obesity.

Summer beamed at the recognition flashing across Piper's countenance. "Oh my gosh, it is you! How long has it been?!"

How long indeed, Piper wondered silently, the memories coming back.

Grade school had been hell. If it wasn't due to the many times she got stuck on the fat-unhappy desks and became the joke of the week, or teased for always eating more than any other kid in class (and at all times), it was definitely because of class bitch Kara Cutter. There's always a Kara Cutter in every fat kid's life. The meanie who tells everyone laughing at others is cool, the self-righteous jerk who insists she's "helping" by taking away your meal and won't give it back unless "you sweat for it".

Naturally, the two resident fat kids from class stuck together. It all started with them being forcibly saddled together, as though their weights made them a different class of species altogether. No one wanted Piper or Summer sitting close to them, so they became the odd ones out, those two fat girls sitting alone together at that table at the end of the room during snack time. But see, life does occasionally look out for the underdogs. Their cruel classmates pinned them together as a mean joke, but in each other, Piper and Summer found kindred spirits, overweight kids made to suffer for the insensitivity of their peers.

They became inseparable, a matching Yin-Yang pairing if there ever was one. Where Piper was olive skinned with raven hair, Summer was pale with ginger locks. Piper was more down to earth in attitude, whereas Summer could be rather jovial and eccentric, which she had said was part of a facade she made to deal with all the bullying.

Presently, Piper smiled warmly in nostalgia at all the good times they'd had.

Sneaking snacks to each other in class, and thus giving their teacher grief every time she caught them in the act. Or that time they were playing at the swing set, taking turns pushing each other on the swing, laughing joyously...which ended in one of them breaking the swing. Or the many slumber parties they had, their respective dotting mothers doing no favors in curbing their appetites with all the sweet snacks they provided for the girls to feast on as they binge watched Disney films.

Or that one particular, special memory when they were older in middle school. When the curiosity for why older boys and girls hold hands or lock lips had gotten the best of them. Since they couldn't get boys to notice them, and they didn't have that many friends, they decided to resolve their curiosity themselves, as best friends who always stuck through everything. This would be no exception.

And so, they became each other's first kiss.

It went about as well as expected for a pair of thirteen-year olds.

"EEEWWWWW!" they had cried as they pulled apart, tongues out as they spat at the grass and asked each other, furiously, why did all those high school boys and girls do that in the first place. Or every mom and dad, for that matter!

They settled to forget about it, and just go get some ice cream, mostly to wash away the terrible taste of sandpaper saliva in their mouths.

Kids.

At some point after that, they just...drifted apart. Summer's family moved elsewhere, they tried to keep in touch, but eventually all manner of communication just stopped. There's only so much to talk about via FaceTime or Skype without forcing conversation and thus making it awkward. And as the years went by, Piper just had a lot on her mind. She shed the weight, she became fully aware of how poorly she and her family's living conditions really were, she fought tooth and nail to graduate from high school, she'd made new friends, and...

Well, here she is.

"Hellooooo? Pipes?" Summer giggled awkwardly. "Are you zoning out on me?"

"Oh, yeah," Piper cleared her throat, a sheepish smile on her face. "Sorry. Got lost in memory lane."

"Ohhhh," Summer said, smiling softly. "Yeah. Me too."

Silence.

"Sooooo," Summer began. "You gonna give me a hug, or just stand there like a busted pipe?"

"Oh, ha-ha," Piper snorted, grinning as she made her way over to her childhood friend.

And registered for the first time that Summer looked...different.

Well, she looks older, yeah. They're not kids anymore. But as Piper took in all of her friend for the first time since turning around to lock faces, it came to her.

Summer...

111311322.content:
Piper's surprise didn't stop her from practically running up to her old school friend and embracing her, feeling the familiar sensation from years past of their large bellies squishing together. It almost made her want to tear up, she felt so happy.

"Oh my gosh, Piper, I missed you SO much," Summer said over her shoulder.

"I really missed you too!" Piper said, choking back tears. "Like...uh, you look great!"

This was in retrospect a silly thing to say considering their weights, but Piper was still hung up on that. Summer being a fatso like her wasn't that much of a shock, but the shape was certainly noticeable. Back before puberty hit the two of them like a bus full of hormones, they were both pretty much round, all belly fat and a healthy layer elsewhere. Now Piper's weight collected in her impressive bosom and upper body, and in keeping with their Yin-Yang pairing, Summer was a sturdy pear. Her belly was a respectable lump that pooched out of her light summer blouse, but below the waist she really started to bloom. Her hips and rear flared out below her waist, crammed into a tight pair of short shorts that opened onto impressively thick legs that ended with a comfy pair of flip-flops. Not that any of that really mattered to Piper; after being neglected by Dakota and Zach most of the summer, she was just happy to find a familiar face.

"Thanks, so do you!" Summer replied cheerfully. "I uh, guess we stayed pretty healthy huh?"

"Uh, yeah I guess so." Both girls laughed guiltily, hyper-aware of how their bellies bounced with laughter.

"What are you even doing out here?" Piper asked in amazement. "I thought you moved to Hesper years ago."

"Well I moved back, I got accepted to Daven's Port U and decided to move out early, get settled in and enjoy the break in my old hometown," Summer explained. "I was worried it was going to be lonely, but here we are, haha! How's your sister doing?"

The two girls quickly got lost in conversation, catching up with one another, regaling stories from their youth, and just whatever else came to mind as they wandered down the pier. They laughed, had fun, even cried a few times. Piper was over the moon, and if she didn't know any better, Summer felt exactly the same way about the chance reunion.

"Hey it's getting pretty late," Summer suddenly said through a mouthful of french fries, one of several purchased that day. "Wow, I didn't even notice."

Piper finished off a large soda and turned to look in the direction of the setting sun. "Shit, you're right, I gotta get home!"

"Yeah me too, the RA is gonna freak if I'm late again," Summer said, rolling her eyes. "You still got my old number right?"

"Yep!" Piper said cheerfully. "Talk to you again tomorrow?"

"You know it!"

Summer gave Piper a mighty squeeze, again blasting her friend with that nostalgic feeling of flab squishing together. As she broke it off and waved goodbye, something caught in the back of Piper's throat and she felt the need to say something.

"Summer...?"

Summer Keegan turned around curiously.

"It's...it's really great to see you again."

Summer smiled warmly. "Great to see you too, Pipes." As they finally departed, Piper ran to get a napkin from a nearby food stall to wipe up her tears, prompting a curious look from the hot dog vendor.

"You alright miss?"

"More then alright," Piper said, happiness overflowing inside of her. "This...this feels like the best summer I've ever had. Oh while I'm here, do you think I can get one for the road? Extra mustard and relish, please?"

---

And so the days of summer rolled on, and the two old friends Piper and Summer quickly became best of friends again. With no Zach and Dakota around, the two spent whole days together, going to all the eateries and stores that Summer missed when she moved but mostly just hanging out and enjoying the summer as best friends do. The people who remembered Summer were always happy to see her back as well, but it seemed the people most happy to see her back, outside of Piper, were Harper and Parker Black. Back in their school days, Summer spent a lot of time at the Black household because of family issues back home, and in time they grew to see Piper's chubby buddy as part of the family. And much like Piper's friendship, that familial relationship came back in full force. They couldn't exactly go on trips and bring her along as they did in the old days given how tight money was, but they made her feel welcome all the same, inviting her to dinner or lunch whenever Harper or Parker was around to make something and letting her sleep over with Piper just like old times.

It wasn't exactly the same, but for Piper close enough was perfect for her. Keegan and Black were back, and as far as Piper was concerned, things couldn't get any better.

But they could get complicated...

11132.content:
"This is the place?" Zack asked with a wry curl of his nose as a musk wafted into the otherwise fresh air, "This can't be right..."

"What? No!" Piper said dismissively, "I just... I don't know. Don't you think that place looks... cool?"

There was a poignant silence between the three of them that suggested that her friends did not agree with her, particularly after having been dragged all across town by a hungry, hungry Piper.

"I mean, if you think so." Dakota finally said, "And, you know.. if it means we don't have to eat anymore..."

"Yeah!" Zack caught on surprisingly quickly "I mean, we can totally take a break for a little while, right? It's not like Steak n Shake closes any time soon!"

If Piper noticed what they were up to, she didn't show it. The pretty punk took a few anxious steps forward, and then decidedly less so, as she guided Zack and Dakota across a surprisingly empty street...

The door chime dinged overhead as the three teenagers made their way inside. The stench of dust and musty old everything was even stronger inside than it was out. The lighting was rather dim, and if buzzed a lot more than she guessed it probably should. It went back surprisingly far, offering plenty of floor space for what looked like useless junk, and opened up to a doorway at the very far back that was draped in one of those bead dividers.

It certainly lived up to its name though; Abida's Eclectics was anything if organized. There were shelves upon shelves upon shelves, trinkets and bobbles lined the walls as armoires and dressers and old fat-back TV's and bookcases cluttered the floors. There were old books, a glass case of jewelry, and a not-surprisingly-large collection of those creepy porcelain angels that every insedit old lady seemed to have handy. All of it dusty.

"Oh, customers?" came a cheery tone, "Wait riiight there!"

From behind the beads, a powerful shape emerged from the deeper levels of the store. One draped in fluorescent colors, providing more than an eyeful of oranges, reds, purples and yellows as it made its way through the beads. A large woman finally emerged, with dark—not tanned, but dark—skin from behind the divider, appearing belly-first as she parted the vaguely eastern pattern. She was dressed in a bright orange dress, wrapped in draped in various scarves with a tightly-tied technicolor head wrap. Beneath that, she had thick black hair that fell into ringlets, which fell onto her meaty shoulders and neck.

"I am Abida, and these are my Eclectics." the woman said with a healthy dose of exposition, "What brings the three of you into my little shop, huh?"

"We mostly wanted to take a break from eating." Zack said, before Dakota raised her arm and gave him a swift punch in the shoulder, "OW!"

"I, uh... I really don't know..." Piper blinked, "I just... I just got the feeling that I should come here."

The round woman smiled warmly at the entranced teenager and stepped behind the counter. She propped herself up on her elbows, her belly cutting thickly into the edge of the counter.

"And should we not all follow our feelings?" the roly-poly shopkeep said, still smiling, "You are quite young to be so intuitive. My shop contains many treasures. I believe that, perhaps, you will find something you like. Yes?"

"Hardly." Zack coughed.

"What do you think, guys?" Piper turned back to her friends, "Think we can put our free food extravaganza on hold a little—"

"YES." Dakota and Zack answered in unison.

With that, Piper turned back into the dusty cavernous expanse of Abida's Eclectics. It went back surprisingly far; like a tooth. There were so many cool pieces on the shelves and on the floor... the only question was... where to start?

Slinking into the back of store, Piper searched throughout the shop. She saw many strange and bizarre things, a pair of shoes with springs on the bottom, a jar of dead moths, and even a Nickelback Album signed “to my biggest fan” that was the weirdest item she saw. Then, in the back, Piper saw something truly eye catching. It was titled Zamboni the Seer, it was made of old musty wood and contained an aging puppet. Its paint was already chipping away, any color on the eyes, it was gone. Piper inspected the machine, she could see the puppet had a crystal ball with cracks between its hands. She looked down to notice a rough rusty metal slot that had some painted writing saying “only 25 cents”. Piper was fascinated by this contraption, she looked to see if the shopkeeper was near.

“Neat, isn’t it?”

Piper jumped, the shopkeeper had been behind her this whole time.

“Yes it is” Piper said hesitantly.

“You know this thing is pretty accurate, maybe it’s better not to know how things will turn out. What do you think?”

Piper was stunned at what the woman said, why would you not at least be curious? Piper was tempted just to see what it said now out of spite.

“Let’s see then.” Piper said while glaring at the woman in the dress.

She took out a quarter, one of the few she had, and put it in. The machine suddenly burst to life. The old hands of the fortune teller moved slowly in a lifelike motion. After a moment, the machine spat out a card into a rusted metal slot below. Piper held her breath.

111322.content:
Rooting through Abida's Eclectics wasn't exactly the easiest task. The roly-poly woman hadn't appeared to have dusted since the turn of the century if the layer of grime and fuzz that layered almost everything was any indication. There were shelves upon shelves, covered in cobwebs and reaching far into the yawning dimness that was the back of the store. Towards the other side, opposite our teenaged trio, only the flickering red EXIT sign lit the way—the rest was only vaguely lit by the natural summer sunlight of the setting Daven's Port skyline.

"Aw geeze it's getting late..." Zack burped, pulling his phone out of his pocket, "Hey P, you uh, you wanna go?"

"Yeah, uh..." Dakota took one look into the graying abyss that was the rear and offered a nervous laugh, "Those milkshakes aren't gonna slurp themselves down!"

But it was no use. Trying to signal to Piper in a worn-down old treasure trove like this may as well have been impossible. She was a connoisseur of all things abandoned on the beach, forgotten and worn down by time. She was the only family on the block—maybe the whole city—with a VCR. Her passion for Polaroids transcended all trendiness, and her well-worn Victrola was her preferred way of playing even the tinniest of pop vinyls. She loved old junk! It came with being one of the poorest people in the neighborhood. Sometimes you never knew what you'd find in a pawn shop, an antique shop... or apparently, an Eclectics shop!

"Aw come on, guys!" Piper whined, taking a few steps forward, away from the light, "There's all kinds of cool stuff here!"

To illustrate her point, Piper started rummaging through Abida's dusty junk. Handprints reversed years of accumulated gray as Piper swept off the grime, Zack and Dakota warily making their way towards the darkness of the inside of the shop. Piper pulled out an old camera, an old cast-iron tea-kettle... you'd think that Abida would have had this organized! But finally, what caught her eye, was a big cardboard box. About the size of one of Bubby Black's old hat boxes. It was faded and brittle—it looked like it might just fall apart if Piper picked it up!

The curious counterculturist swept a hand across one side of the box, a film of dead gray yielding to her touch.

"The What-If? Machine..." Piper read aloud, "Fun for the whole family, ages 8 to 80..."

It was an old board game! An old board game, by the looks of it. It was about six inches tall and two feet long by one foot wide. The box, once thoroughly wiped down, had a yellow and red color scheme (albeit somewhat faded) and illustrations of a family gathered around a small television screen. Hmm. Piper wasn't much into board games. She hadn't so much as touched the thrift-store copy of Monopoly that had gone neglected in the top of the Black Family communal closet down the hall. So why was it, then, that she was so drawn to this one?

"You're not seriously gonna buy that thing, are you?" Zack ribbed her, "I mean not when there's... Home Alone on VHS Christ alive this place is a junkheap."

"Be nice." Dakota gave Zack a quiet shove, "The owner's like, right there!"

And sure enough, there was Abida. She was bobbing out from behind the counter, her impressive bosom and heaving gut bouncing with every excited step. She held her chubby hands high above her chest and huffed and puffed eagerly as she made her way over to Piper, who was still crouched down holding her find.

"Ah yes, I remember this!" Abida said in her broad accent, "The What-If? Machine! Everyone had one when I was a girl!"

"Really?" Piper asked, one black brow cocked inquisitively, "I've never heard of it."

"It's an older game." Abida said with a slight cough, probably hoping to dissuade anyone from inquiring further, "There was some sort of licensing issues with the big name toy brands. I had thought that all of these fell by the wayside—imagine my surprise to find this here, in my shop!"

"Well maybe if you actually cleaned—OW!!"

Piper held the box in her hands. It certainly felt old. The cardboard around the game was brittle, and the paint was flaking off. But there was definitely something heavy inside! A quick inspection told her that, yes, all of the pieces were in place and the monitor was undamaged. How it worked, exactly, Piper couldn't say. But it looked to be in great condition. Maybe she could sell it?

"How much do you want for it?" Piper asked, surprising almost everyone in the room, "The game?"

"Ah? I could never part with such a treasure..." Abida gave a longing look at the What If? Machine, her sausagey digits rap-tap-tapping on the edge of the box, "...for anything less than ten dollars."

"Sold." Piper said with a smile, her hands plunging into her tight pockets and reemerging with a crumbled $10 bill, "Best ten bucks I ever spent!"

As the sun set and the three teens left, Dakota and Zack couldn't have been more happy to get out of that old shop and back into the natural sunlight, no matter how fleeting it may have been. Piper seemed to have more or less forgotten about the free milkshakes from Steak n Shake—apparently she was a bit more full now that all her free samples had had time to settle. As the orange-colored sky flickered into reds, to purples, to black, the three teens came into view of the Black Family household...

The screen door clanged as it shut behind her, Piper offering a goodbye wave as her friends walked down and out of her driveway.

"Bye guys, had fun!" she yelled through the mesh screening into the Summer air, "Let's meet up again Tuesday, okay? I still wanna try those milkshakes!"

And with that, the door was shut. Piper turned tail back into the kitchen. The fluorescent lighting flickered over the stove as the smell of pizza filled the whole house. From the front door, Piper could see her older sister vegging out on the couch. At least she'd moved since this morning—her hangover couldn't have been that bad. On the coffee table, in front of her feet, were two open boxes of meat lover's supreme from Pagliacci Pizza. Her sister leaned against the arm of the sofa, a greasy triangle in hand, as her eyes slowly shifted to see Piper standing in the doorway.

"Way to miss family night, you turd." Parker snorted, "Mom's pissed."

Oh shit. Family night! How could Piper have forgotten?

It had been her stupid idea in the first place, to have a night where they all got together and did shit so that they could start getting along better before the baby arrived. Piper had pushed so hard for everyone to agree to one night a week where everyone put aside their stupid bullshit and came together. Even Parker had agreed, albeit under direct threat of eviction, to set aside hanging out with her idiot club friends for a night in with the family.

And of all people, Piper had been the one to miss it?

"Oh shit, really?" Piper placed the game down on the kitchen table, "Please tell me you're fucking with me."

"Nah, I am." Parker sneered, "She thinks this whole family night thing is stupid too."

"But I am pissed that you forgot to go by D's." came the sudden inclusion of her mother's voice from somewhere deeper into the living room, "Your sister and I ordered pizza—I am so pissed at you for wrecking my diet, Piper! I'M GONNA BE A WHALE BY THE TIME THIS BABY COMES!"

Sitting in the living room were the remaining members of the Black family. Parker, Piper's older sister, sat on the left.

She was something of an older version of her sister. There was a strong family resemblance in all the Black women, beginning with a prominent but attractive nose and set of eyebrows. Parker kept her hair short and straightened, but shared a similar taste with her younger sister. Parker liked t-shirts and cigarette jeans on days she stayed in, only trading up for fancier getups when she went out to the club. Which was often. Like the rest of the women (and some of the men!) in her family, Parker was very well-endowed; although a bit more pallid.

To the right, on the other end of the couch, Piper's mom had parked herself in a very similar situation as her eldest daughter.

In her youth, Harper had looked very much like her daughters. And while the natural sort of curves that came with motherhood and being in her thirties had done well to set her apart by her wide hips and slightly softer figure, that resemblance had stayed true. She didn't look her age ("We Black girls are blessed with longevity!") although her fashion hinted at it sometimes. Her frizzy black 'do was eighties big, and she had a bent for early ninties wear. The swell of her pregnant stomach, nearly five months along, housed Piper's littlest sister, to be named Hunter. She, too, looked to have been enjoying herself.

Two boxes of pizza lay empty on the table before Piper's family, the remainder of the third being slowly enjoyed by the shirked relatives without a hint of remorse.

"Sorry Mom..." Piper offered weakly, "I just got held up hanging out with Zack and Dee..."

"It's fine, don't worry about it. I'm just happy you're hanging out with people who don't have criminal records." Harper puffed, "Just get this pizza away from me. I'm craving grease and I'd like to not clog an artery before the night's over."

Honestly, the sight and smell of anymore food was beginning to wear on Piper as it was. Eating all day, even at free sample sizes, hadn't exactly been the smartest decision that Piper had ever had. She was getting green around the gills just looking at it!

"Hey, whatcha got in there?" Parker suddenly asked, looking into the kitchen and on the table at Piper's recent acquisition

"That?" Piper turned readily away from the cheesy triangle, "Oh, I uh, checked out that shop in downtown. It's an old boardgame. Thought I'd... I don't know, sell it on eBay?"

Was that even a thing? Was there a market for old boardgames on the internet? Surely one that was discontinued a while back (at least far enough back for Abida to remember it) would have some pull. Either it was a collector's item or it was better off in the dust where Piper had found it. But as she said it out loud, somehow Piper felt... wrong? Like she shouldn't want to sell it? Did that makes sense? It certainly didn't to her...

"Ugh. Who's gonna wanna buy some dusty old board game?" Parker snorted, finishing off her crust, "I'll bet it doesn't even work."

"Neither do you, but we keep you around." Piper raised her eyebrows at her sister, "I mean, does it matter if it works? People will buy anything on the internet."

"I don't know..." her mother interjected, "I worked pretty hard to get my seller score up to 5 stars... how do you know it works?"

"Because... because I just do, okay?!" Piper sputtered, "Jesus, I didn't know that Family Night meant the Spanish Inquisition."

It took some coaxing, but eventually Piper's mom rocked herself out of her seated position on the couch and toddled her way over to the kitchen table. She looked at it much the same as Piper had about an hour beforehand. She put both her hands on either side of the box, dusted it, wiped away some grime that Piper had missed, and looked absolutely fascinated. Like she was seeing a friend for the first time in a long time.

"I remember these!" she finally said, putting the box back down on the table, "I saw a commercial for it one time when I was a kid. I asked your Bubby for it, but we never had the money. They were yanked off the shelves for some reason, and there were never any more ever made!"

It was with an almost childlike glee that Harper opened the box. She slipped the top off and placed everything out on the table. The monitor, the battery pack (THOSE would have to be replaced...), the microphone, warranty card, and finally the instruction booklet all wound up on the kitchen table. Piper's pregnant mom rushed over to the junk drawer, further into the kitchen, and returned with two D batteries.

"So what do you do?" Parker asked, still seated from the couch, "How do we work this antique, O Ancient One?"

"I don't know, smartass." Piper's mom bit back, "I just told you I never had one. None of my friends did either. Shit, I didn't think anyone in this town ever got one. But here we are."

Piper stood back as she watched her mom fiddle with the back of the monitor. She unscrewed the piece at the bottom and popped the batteries into the back end. With the flip of a switch, it came to life! A soft blue glow filled the room on one side as Harper looked on excitedly at their newest acquisition.

"Wow..." Harper squealed, "I can't believe it still works!"

"We should... uh..." Piper grabbed the instruction booklet and pawed through it, "We should ask it a question!"

"What?" Parker asked exasperatedly, pausing their Redbox rental for the umpteenth time, "Piper, that's fucking stupid. It's not a magic eight ball."

"Well, I mean... it's kinda like that." Harper conceded, "I remember that the commercial said you could ask it anything—as long as it was a What-If question—and it would tell you what would happen."

Ooh. Now that sounded promising. Asking a machine anything, as long as it was a What If? That... there was no way that this was real.

"There's no way that this is real." Piper laughed, "You're fucking with us, right?"

"Well, I don't know because I never had one of these when I was a kid.." Harper put her hands on her wide hips, "Criminy, Piper, learn to listen—I'm going off what I remember from a commercial when I was six."

There was a long pause as all three women, even Parker, stared at the humming blue screen in their kitchen. If their mom was right, this could be the best thing that ever happened to them. Something like this had to go for thousands on eBay. A nostalgic toy collector would pay out the ass for something like this. But if Harper was right about it being able to tell the future...or rather, the alternate present... it might be worth at least a spin or two.

"Well, I mean, we have to make sure it works..." Piper shrugged, pulling up a chair, "You know, so we can sell it for more money."

"I agree." Harper nodded, chair legs scraping against the linoleum, "And you do owe me a family night..."

All eyes turned to Parker...

"Oh fine." Parker paused the TV again, "But only because Mom threatened to kick me out, and I really don't feel like pushing any more buttons tonight."

The three women were seated around the ancient piece of technology like an old-fashioned seance. The screen stared them in the face, casting its blue light against them. The microphone was on the table, an equal distance between all of them.

The only question was...

Who's turn was it?

"Ah, yeah, that might be a good idea,” Harper nodded wisely. “And we can best check it by asking. And since it's my turn anyway… What if I won the jackpot tomorrow?”

The machine whirred again, a lot longer this time, then the screen lightened again and the three Black women saw… themselves. They were sitting on the couch, their eyes glued onto the TV while it was announcing winning numbers and just as the vision cleared, Video Parker sceptically scoffed: “Say whatever you like, I still don't believe in miraculous medium machines.”

“Shush! Not now!” Video Harper held a ticket in her hand, checking each and every one of the numbers the announcer called out. “Wait, wait… and now 42!”

“42,” the TV obeyed her command.

“Yes! Yesss! I'm rich! I'm finally filthy rich! I'm a millionaire!” Video Harper threw her hands up while Piper and Parker danced a little jig.

“Well, that was interesting,” Parker sighed wistfully as the screen faded to black again, “but didn't help us much. We still don't know the first winning two numbers. In fact, we don't even know whether it's real or not...”

"Oh, sure it's real, you party pooper! Didn't you see it there?”

“Yeah, on the screen of a cheap ancient toy. Do you really believe everything you see on TV, Mom?” she scoffed.

The two bickering women didn't even notice Piper disappear upstairs. She had an idea to test but needed her all-but-forgotten school notebook for it. Now she jogged down with it in hand and while her family was still arguing over the validity of what they had just seen, she leaned to the microphone. “What if I bet on the winning numbers?”

Screen cleared again, showing Piper come to the counter in a rather shabby convenience shop.

“I know that place! It's that 7-Eleven on the next corner!” exulted Parker.

“Shush and listen,” Harper knew this no longer worked, she could no longer rein in her older daughter. Luckily Parker realised her mistake and stopped speaking on her own.

Just in time. “Hi, I came to place a jackpot bet.” Video Piper held up her school notebook and quickly rushed out a sequence of numbers, so fast the clerk could barely manage to put them in, once he even had to ask again to clarify.

“What? What? Did you get it? Anyone?” Harper glanced around, confused. “I swear I had a pen here somewhere… Was it 37? Or 47?”

“Nonsense, Mom. She said 57, just like the TV announcer before. Why don't you pay attention… Hey! Where're you goin'?!”

But Piper was already gone. Clutching her notebook close to stop her breasts wobbling too much, she ran all the way to the local 7-Eleven. She burst inside, stopping only at the empty counter to catch her breath.

The shop was utterly devoid of customers so the clerk was dozing in a corner. Now her steps woke him up. “Yeth?” he asked groggily.

“Hi, I came to place a jackpot bet,” Piper tried to mimic the words her on-screen counterpart had used, “it is 4-8-15-25-37-42,” she said breathlessly, reading the numbers from her notebook.

“Eh, not so fast. Did you say 37 or 47?”

“37.” She paid him ten dollars (her last), the clerk handed her a slip of paper and thanked her, going to sleep again. She left the shop… and right into an arm that snatched her aside.

“What're you doin', Pipes?!” Her older sister did not look happy.

“Experimenting,” shrugged Piper.

“But- But- You can't just go and place the bet yourself! We're in this together, all three of us!”

“Sure,” Piper was just about telling Parker that it was her game and why was she so concerned all of a sudden when according to her opinion it could never work. But she swallowed it all when she saw a small crowd (several suspicious characters drawn from God knows where) gathering around to see what the commotion was about. “So good of you to remind me. If we don't win, you owe me 3 dollars 33 cents. Come on, let's go home.”

“What?! Owe you?! But...”

“We're in this together, remember?” and she lowered her voice. “Tomorrow we'll see if it works. Just imagine what we could do if it does!”

“And what debts we could run up if it doesn't,” Parker replied sourly.

"Are you though?" Dakota continued. "You're not worried that I could get...bigger? Rounder?"
