"Uh..."

"I swear Piper," Dakota smiled seductively. "You are making me so...damned...fat..."

Video Piper's hands immediately shot out towards her girlfriend's gut, but before she could go further Video Parker returned from the rear.

"Here ya go, two dozen and a sampler!" the elder Video Black sibling said happily, handing the whole collection to an aroused looking Video Piper. "Enjoy your food!"

"Oh I think I will," Video Dakota said, still smiling as her girlfriend rounded on her. "I'm quite...hungry today."

Before the side show could continue, the screen mercifully faded into nothingness once again. There was a moment of silence, then Parker Black cleared her throat.

"So...is there something you want to tell us about, sis?" Parker said with a grin.

"Shut the fuck up," Piper grumbled, wanting nothing more then to sink into the ground right now.

"Oh, calm down you two, it's just an alternate universe image!" Harper said indignantly. "Have a little fun with it!"

"Fine, but I get the next question, and it's not going to involve any food!" Piper snapped.

"Okay here's a question, what if I socked you in the nose right this second?"

"Okay mom," Parker sighed. "Piper, can you do your question already?"

112.content:
Okay, so having a pregnant mother didn’t exactly make life easy.

Especially since, thanks to a certain asshole father, she was unemployed at the time of pregnancy because he was the paltry breadwinner of the house and no one wants to hire a woman who was about to literally shoot out another, smaller, noisier woman in less than a trimester. Piper’s Mom had been having an especially hard divorce, so money was tight, but she was also having an especially difficult pregnancy. Which was where Piper stepped in to help take care of things where she could.

“Where’re you going?” her sister, Parker, grumbled from the couch, “Hanging out with your little boyfriend again?”

“What? No. Ew.” Piper rolled her eyes as she handled the doorknob, “I’m gonna go out and do some crap for Mom. Zack’s not my... ew!”

Piper and Parker had been at each other’s throats since the day Piper had been born. Parker had been the kind of older sister to try to return Piper to the stork just a week after she’d been born. And then try to take her to the UPS store on her big wheel when that didn’t work. And then, when all else failed, try to flush her sister down the toilet like a dead goldfish. Parker was about four years older than Piper, and took every opportunity to remind her of it by going out and drinking, partying, blowing whatever money came her way and earning the rest of it without scruples. Like Piper she was stacked, with tan olive skin and thick black hair cut short above her shoulders. Unlike Piper, she was seriously hung over, and dressed in her jammies.

“Okay, so your girlfriend.” Parker said with her eyes shut as she laid on the couch, “The one from Arizona.”

“Dakota, Texas, and no.” Piper rolled her eyes as she opened the door, “Bye Parker.”

“Deuces.” Parker spat back as the door shut behind her little sister...

***


The streets of Daven’s Port had always been a more welcome home to Piper than her actual home had ever been. The people knew her name, they didn’t complain when she got stuff wrong, and nobody (well, nobody she’d ever encountered) was hung over on a regular basis. The shop owners on the pier knew her, the street merchants gave her free hot dogs sometimes; life out here was usually a lot better than life in there.

Most of her issues came from Parker, unsurprisingly. She had always been a pain in the ass, but it was like ever since Dad left she had gone out of her way to be as un-helpful as possible. Which, with her constant partying and binge drinking, turned out to be very unhelpful. For God’s sake, their mom was pregnant and she didn’t even want to get a job to help keep food on the table...

Ugh, no time to dwell on all that now.

Piper’s Mom had been getting cravings out her wazoo ever since she entered her third trimester. Maple syrup on everything, off-brand chocolate from the gas station and only the gas station, midnight ice cream binges that nobody woke her up for... it was starting to get a little hard to keep up with!

Especially since, once again, it all fell on Piper to make sure that she got what she needed.

She couldn’t drive, so it wasn’t like she could go pick up the week’s worth of groceries it would take to feed everyone. But she could at least go out and get a few things to make life a little easier. Everything in Daven’s Port was just a long walk or a bus ride away. And thankfully, her mom’s cravings were just diverse enough that she could still get out and stretch her legs, see some friendly faces while she shopped.

“Ah, c’est Piper!” came the jovial, foreign tone of the best baker in town, “Come in, come in! I have just put, eh, chocolate croissants in ze oven!”

Basil Moreau was just one of the many folks in Daven’s Port who had succumbed to Piper’s charm. He was a plump french immigrant (legal, she figured) with two kids. He owned La Bonne Boulangerie, which seemed to cater exclusively to chocoholics and her mother. She had started coming in during her sophomore year and by now, after she’d just graduated a month ago, the Moreaus were like old family friends.

“‘Ow iz your mama, huh?” Basil asked with a smile behind his tweedily french moustache, “Still, uh... eh?”

He held out his hands in front of his belly to pantomime a larger, supposedly pregnant belly.

“Yeah, she’s still pretty eh. Kinda the reason I’m here.” Piper said with a smile as she whipped out her phone and started reading off her mom’s list, “I need, uh... a chocolate cake and... an order of sugar cookies and...”


Suffice it to say, Piper walked out of that place with half the damn bakery in tow.

Only her mother could crave such an inordinate amount of sugar during her pregnancy. She said she always had a craving for something when she was pregnant with her and her sister. With her it had been ice (which is why she was so cool! ba-dum-dum-tiss!) and with Parker it had been dirt. Her mom often joked that, because of all the sweets she’d been eating, this child was going to turn out a lot sweeter than her other ones.

It better.

Because Piper was not doing all this running around, giving up being the baby of the family, and hooking her mom up with enough sweets to induce a diabetic coma to raise another Parker.

As the doorbell chimed behind her, Piper waving a goodbye to the jovial baker inside, her phone started to vibrate.

It was a text from her mom!

"Hey Piper while youre out would you mind...?
112.title: Piper Daughter is Best Daughter

1122.content:
Piper couldn't help but roll her eyes as she read her mom's message. She's already been out burglaring bakeries all morning, so why wouldn't she want to run right out and get fast food too? It's not like she was an octopus—where was she supposed to put all this stuff on the way home?

But Piper had learned over the course of her life, and especially since her Mom's hormones had started going into overdrive, that there were some battles that could be fought, and others that it was just best to let them be. A hungry, cravings-fueled pregnant woman was not an opponent Piper was in the mood to face right about now.

"Sure thing, Mom." She said aloud as she typed out her response, "Nevermind the fact that I've got exactly one free hand and you totally won't pay me back..."

***


Growing up, Piper and her family never did much eating out. Because, you know, that costs money. Even when her Dad was around, and when there was actually income coming in, eating out was reserved for special occasions. Birthdays, good grades, and general bribery were usually the only reasons that Piper would walk through the glass double doors of places like Big Burger. Granted that had changed lately, on days that Mom didn't feel like cooking particularly, but the smell of grease and fast food still wasn't something that Piper had gotten used to.

Big Burger was this chain that reached all across the nation (supposedly—Piper never got far past the Port). It had this retro 50's thing going on. Chrome walls and tables, red everything else. The employees wore white uniforms with dopey little paper hats. There was a long silver counter where you placed your order on one side and got it on the other.

Piper had guessed it was pretty popular, judging by the fact that it was a Tuesday afternoon and the whole place was jumpin'.

Summer time in Daven's Port meant that all the stupid teenagers (herself included) were out of school and had officially moved into "free-range" territory. Mindless, wandering drones capable only of satisfying their baser urges like cramming fries into their face and complaining about people they didn't like or shows they'd seen on TV.

Not taking care of a pregnant mother... Piper mentally added with a roll of her eyes.

Anyway, suffice it to say, the wait to place her order was a long one. And the box of baked goods held by the handle seemed to get heavier with every customer in front of her...

"Hey there, welcome to Big Burger!" Said a perky little redhead in one of those stupid hats, "Would you like to try our Memphis BBQ Big Burger today? It's a dollar off!"

"No thanks. I mean, I would except, you know, the order's not for me and... well, you get it." Piper prattled as she whipped out her phone with her free hand, tapping it awake and squinting at her Mom's very specific instructions, "Lemme get a, uh... Big Double Cheeseburger, extra onions no pickles... a Big Fish Sandwich, extra mayonnaise, some fries..."

Piper could have sworn that the line got longer by the time she was finished. That poor little twat behind the counter couldn't keep up with her order if her life depended on it! So she had to keep going back, repeating herself, correcting her mistakes... Why was it so damn hard to listen to what she was saying and push a damn button?

Okay, fine, a series of damn buttons.

Ugh... how was it that her mom the pregnant one and she was the one who was so grouchy all the time?

At least it didn't take long for her order to be ready. The sweaty teens working in the kitchen plopped a fresh, greasy bag of fast food right in front of her and called out her order number. Juggling her phone and her mom's bakery bundle, Piper did her best to grab the bag with her remaining few fingers. She managed, somehow, and started walking towards the door...

BVVT BVVVT!

Piper felt her phone vibrate in her hands and barely contained what would have been a very audible groan of displeasure. It was probably her mom asking her what was taking so long.

Oh look, surprise surprise, it was! Now Piper not only had to carry everything out all the way home before the grease managed to eat through the bag, she also had to henpeck her pointer finger on the keyboard so her mom didn't—WOOF!

Piper suddenly collided into something—both her parcels fell right to the ground, along with her phone!

"Ah shit, sorry about that..." Piper shot down to the ground, "I-I'm in kind've a hurry y'know? Really sorry..."

Piper looked up, only to find that she'd bumped into...

11221.content:
"Oh you're in a hurry, huh?" Came an all-too-familiar tone of voice, "To go where, Pitstain? Back to whatever gutter you crawled out of?"

Standing above her, eclipsing the tacky fluorescent lighting that reflected off of every-fucking-thing ever so slightly, was the girl who had been the bane of Piper's existence for the better part of her adolescent life. The girl who had picked on her for being poor, for her sister being a slut, for the music she liked, and for how she dressed literally from the day they were enrolled in the same high school—Kara Cutter. She was the one piece of baggage that Piper had honestly thought she had left behind on the graduation stage.

And now here she was, staring her in the face like she was right back in high school.

Goddammit.

"Oh, it's just you." Piper dropped the niceties, narrowing her brown eyes to olive slits at the sight of her most heinous enemy, "I'm sorry, I thought I bumped into a person. Instead of, you know, a trash can."

"You're calling me trash?" Kara scoffed from behind her cheap, $3 sunglasses from Claire's, "That's rich."

Kara was everything that Piper hated about high school, all summed up into one person. She was one of those girls who was completely obsessed with where everyone was and what they were doing, constantly on her phone and talking incessantly about this person or that person. She lived on the better side of town, and came from a pretty well-off family, but she still dressed like a beach rat. Halter tops, cutoffs, flip flops. With her cheap-looking platinum blonde dye job and those aforementioned sunglasses—UGH. Piper friggin hated her!

"Look, unless you haven't noticed, this is a place of business. Not highschool." Piper waved a hand out for all bitches to see, "Don't want any trouble. Just tryin' to get my mom some food here—you and I have no beef."

"Yeah, only 'cause you can't afford it." Kara's sneer intensified, "In the sense that you know I can kick your ass and, you know, you're poor and literally can't afford it."

Piper felt her chest puff out. The fire in her belly started roaring. She'd been taking shit from Kara for four years, and she'd never once just decked her one. It would have solved her problems in freshman year, and it would solve her problems now. All it would take was one good sunglasses-shattering punch, and Kara Cutter would be out of her life for the better...

BVVT! BVVT!

IF only her phone hadn't made her hesitate. Her mom would kill her if she got into another fight. On public property. Where she could be arrested. Or at the very least, be reprimanded by the police for so long that her food got cold and/or stale. Piper had to be the good daughter. To take care of her mom. Even if it meant not dealing with bitches like Kara Cutter who seriously needed to be dealt with.

"408!" The kid from behind the counter called out.

In Piper's moment of hesitation, she saw Kara's eyes flick over to the counter. The receipt in her hands had 408 in big black lettering, held so that Piper could just make it out. A small smile spread across her face when she realized that Kara's short shorts were looking a little tight. There was a slight curvature to her usually very flat stomach. Piper looked her up and down for show, which caused Kara to brace herself for impact. Poor little confrontational Kara must have been shocked when all Piper had to say was:

"Enjoy your food, Kara." with a little snort as she walked out the door

"Yeah, well, I will!" Kara called out, loud enough to attract some attention, "You...you fucking transient!"

11222.content:
"Oh no ma'am, I'm—Piper?" came a distinctly familiar tone, "Is that you?"

Piper looked up at the mention of her name, having never expected to run into anyone here who would have known her. But sure enough, there standing above her, was an old face that thought she would have never seen again! It had been so long, but there was no mistaking Cierra Collins—like, the one person who made living in her neighborhood bearable. At least, until she moved on up to Midtown. After she graduated, Piper had to go through a whole year of high school without her! With everything that had been going on, she had almost completely forgotten about her!

"Oh my god, Cierra!" Piper leapt off of the floor with a squeal as she wrapped her arms around her long lost friend, "I haven't seen you in forever!"

"Well, I've been here." the older girl said as she wrapped her soft brown arms around Piper's shoulders and gave her a good squeeze, "Where have you been? You, like, dropped off the face of the earth!"

Piper hadn't much time for social interaction with everything that had been going on in her life. What with the divorce and the pregnancy and dealing with it all in her own patented "fuck you stay out of my business" way. It had been a hard year! In her defense though, Cierra was already a year older than Piper. She had graduated a few months before Piper's dad left. It had just been so hard to make time to see each other, but now... it was just so good to see her!

"Easy girl, I am on the clock you know." Cierra said with a final squeeze before separating herself from Piper, "Can't let my manager think I just come up and molest all our customers."

Cierra was in the exact opposite position as Piper right about now. Her single mother with two kids lucked out and married some computer guy, and it wasn't long until they moved to the better side of town once they could afford it. Why she was working here when her family had more money to play around with than Piper could shake a fist at was another question, but one for a later time.

"So you work here, huh?" Piper raised an eyebrow, "Well I guess that explains the uniform. And the stupid hat."

"You don't like the hat?" Cierra frowned as she took it off her head, "I think it's cute!"

"No, Cee, it's not." Piper shook her head, "Not cute."

"Like a little sailor?"

"No."

It was nice to know that, out of all the changes she'd been facing the past few months, Cierra had managed to stay more or less the same since Piper had last seen her. She had a new hairdo, and she'd filled out a little, but Cierra was still very much the same little street rat that she used to skip classes and loiter with. Cierra's wide hips strained the fabric on her white pants, and Piper could see her breasts spilling over the cups of her bra through her button-up.

"Woah there, what's with the door stopper?" Cierra said as she noticed Piper's order, sitting on the floor, "You hungry, Piper?"

"What? No." Piper laughed, "Just cravings."

"What?" Cierra's brown eyes shot open, "You're pregnant?"

"No no no no, Mom." Piper corrected herself, "Mom's pregnant. I'm just the delivery girl."

"Oh!" Cierra's expression flipped, "Well in that case...
11222.title: Getting Reacquainted with an Old Friend

11223.content:
A guy in a hurry bustled passed Piper, yacking away on his cell phone. He turned briefly to acknowledge her, and the spilled cake stuck to the floor, and shrugged as he headed out the door.

"Yeah, fuck you TOO asshole!" Piper yelled after him, loud enough the employees to jump, before realizing a fight wasn't going to happen, and sipping back into their routine. It made Piper feel better for a moment. But only for a moment. After that the depression and gnawing anxiety of poverty sunk in. She numbly watched as an employee brought a push broom and started cleaning up the sad remains of the cake and the scattered cookies across the floor. God, was there anything sadder than a spilled cake?

There was no money to get another one. There was, honestly, no money for that one, but she had tapped into their remaining reserves anyway. And that money would be gone forever. Because thee was no money coming in, just a dwindling supply.

And Piper was tired of it. As she left Big Burger she came to a decision. She was going to have to turn their financial situation around, above all, she was going to turn HER financial situation around, no matter what it took.

---

That night, Piper set to work with trembling fingers. Parker was out on the town, hopefully she'd be gone until dawn. But her mother was in the other room, behind paper thin walls. She had explained the situation, and Harper understood, but she could tell it was a blow to her. Sometimes Piper wondered how much the food cravings were the result of pregnancy, and how much of them were her way of dealing with the stress of finances.

Well, Piper reminded herself, she was fixing that. If her mother barged in, she would explain that, and understand, she hoped. Maybe she even would be grateful! Maybe. It was a household full of liberated women, kind of.

Piper took a picture of her learners permit, and uploaded it to her computer. The birthdate clearly indicated that she was 18 years old…for the last 4 days. The birthday party had been rather subdued this year. Still, it counted. This would all be legal and above board.

Next she took a picture of herself. The kind of selfie she usually avoided. She tugged at the neckline of a halter top she had stolen from Parker giving the camera a lens full of olive cleavage. Some clever cropping hid her hand, and the fact that her shirt couldn't possibly hang like that, and even the fact that there was a limit to her cleavage. It just plunged off the bottom of the frame, making it seem like she had boobs as big as you could imagine.

A profile name, and a few minutes to for them to verify her ID and she was ready. This was happening. Piper Black, Cam Girl. She had thought about this a while, even before her father left. It's not like they could ever turn down the money, and when you're stacked like Piper, you don't make it through puberty without a few men 'suggesting' a few ways to make easy money. But now, pushed over by this latest desperation, Piper couldn't imagine not taking the easy money. "Let's do this." she said, before turning on the cam, and opening a room.

And then…nothing. There was no one there. For twenty long, agonizing minutes. And during that time the butterflies in her stomach died and turned sour. The first one popped in then immediately logged off. That hurt her confidence even more.

One of the areas where this was most evident was, of course, the attic—why bother cleaning when you could just shove some stuff upstairs, right?

Piper and Parker hadn't been up there since they were little girls. They used to keep the Christmas Tree up here, before it caught fire that one time. So since Piper was about ten, she hadn't so much as set foot upstairs. And why would she? It wasn't like there was anything up there of hers. Or Parker's for that matter.

God, her mom had a lot of junk.

Why was this her responsibility again?

"Ugh! Mom's got so much shit up here!" Parker griped, "Why is this our responsibility again?"

"Shut up, Parker." Piper rolled her eyes, "Just... get up here. And don' touch that pink stuff."

Avoiding the insulation, Piper and Parker Black deftly crawled up into the attic of their more-than-humble abode. It wasn't exactly spacious up there, and boy was it hot. Piper could already feel thick beads of sweat forming above her prominent black brow, and she felt moist somehow. This damn Summer heat.

"Alright, you start over there..." Piper grunted as she worked her way to a hunched standing position, "And I'll start over here. It shouldn't take us more than a few hours to get everything—"

"Oh my gawwwd..." Parker was acting like a child, as if doing this one thing was going to kill her, "This is gonna take forever!"

"Suck it up, butt munch." Piper punched her sister in the arm, causing a wince and recoil from the older Black sister, "Mom asked us to do, like one thing. If we don't bitch and we don't whine, it shouldn't take us more than a few hours to get everything sorted."

There was a heavy pause as Parker dragged herself to the other side of the attic and started pouring through boxes.

"Who knows?" Piper said aloud, mostly to herself, "We might even find something cool..."
11322.title: Cleaning Out the Attic

choices: A book of magical origin!
A collection of glass vials filled with strange liquids!
Something else entirely!
113221.content:
"Hey...Parker?"

"Yo?"

"I kinda want to die."

"Saaame..."

It had been hours since the two sisters started the big attic cleaning, and they were feeling every second of it. Parker was too exhausted to even open her mouth and whine about being exhausted at this point, and Piper was fighting the urge to take out her frustration on all of her Mom's chintzy garbage.

"Least we got...one more thing..." Piper wheezed as she stumbled towards the back of the attic, drenched in so much sweat that her shirt and hair were plastered to her skin. Parker moaned in agony, pounding her head against a sturdy support beam in frustration. "H-hey...chin up sis...nearly done...then pizza..." Parker fumbled about as she turned the heavy box around, trying to see if it had been labeled at all. She craned her neck to get a better look at the other side and-

HISSSSSSS

"AAAAAAGH!"

Piper flung herself back in shock whacking her head on another support beam. Stars popped in front of her eyes as the angry possum hiding behind the box scurried away, slipping out the broken roof window and out of sight. Piper tried to get to her feet, but something creaked overhead and seconds later a big heavy object dropped from the roof, landing squarely on her lady parts.

"Hurrk!" Piper choked, clutching at her nethers as she gently flopped onto her side.

"Holy fuck, Piper," the older sister said as she stumbled over the rafters. "Are you okay?"

Piper looked up at her sister, glaring through tears of pain.

"Okay, stupid question," Parker admitted.

---

A few moments later, and with Parker's assist, the punk teenager was lying on the sofa recuperating from the assault on her ladynads, her legs twisted around her to protect herself from unwanted blows. In the other room, the attic door was slammed shut and Parker reappeared, offering Piper one of the two cans of Pepsi she had on her.

"Thanks for keeping it interesting, I guess," Parker commented.

"Fuck you," Piper mumbled, snatching one of the cans and opening it up with a pressurized hiss.

"Hey, at least we'll still get pizza!" Parker said brightly. Her attitude had improved tremendously, possibly because she felt protective after seeing her curled up in pain for the past few minutes. Piper grunted, the feeling starting to come back to her at the refreshing taste of an ice cold drink. "Right," Parker went on. "So everything's labeled and sorted, except for, like that one last box that I couldn't open."

"Last box?"

"You know, the one that tried to sterilize you?" Parker leaned down to pick up an ornate, carved wooden box and set it on the coffee table. "Like, I wonder where mom got it, I can't seem to open it." Piper reached out to run a hand over it, feeling how warped and ragged the surface was.

"Are you sure this belongs to mom?" Piper asked. "It looks really fucking old..."

"I dunno, she like has a lot of antiques though, doesn't she?"

Piper lifted up her hand, coated in dust and old wood shavings. "If this was an antique it wouldn't be peeling this badly." Turning it over in her hands, she gave it a shake, not hearing anything jostling around. Finding a rusted iron lock built into the side, Piper dug around in her pockets and pulled out a paper clip she was fiddling around with earlier, straightening it and sticking it into the lock on the side of the box.

"Piper that's not gonna-"

"Got it!"

Parker's mouth dropped open a little bit as the lid of the box lifted slightly, the locks popping open with a cheery metal ping. "Since when could you pick locks?"

"Sis, is that really a question you want an answer to?"

"...no, no it isn't," Parker admitted. "Seriously though, what's in this thing?"

Piper carefully opened the old box, its hinges rusting over and decrepit and inside the felt-lined interior was...
113221.title: What's In The Box?

choices: What the hell, bottom's up! Piper drinks one of the vials.
Piper passes up, more for Parker!
1132212.content:
Piper carefully opened the old box, its hinges rusting over and decrepit, and inside the felt-lined interior was a small collection of glassware.

The box was about a foot tall and just as wide, and it was the heavy wood lent it the heft it needed to nearly cave in Piper's crotch. It opened up from the top a good two inches down, decrepit and rusted metal squealing at being disturbed from their slumber as Piper slowly lifted the heavy lid back to reveal the box's contents.

"Oh sweet its a liquor box!" Parker said suddenly and excitedly

"Parker what the fuck is a liquor box?" Piper leaned back and gave her sister a decent 'you're the biggest idiot I know' face

"Yeah, like some rich people used to keep their alcohol in personalized little boxes and shit way back when." she sounded all too certain about her hypothesis as she extended one hand over Piper's shoulder and towards one of the vials, "C'mon, lemme see."

Piper allowed her sister to take one of the vials from its crevice carved into the wood and felt. Parker took one of the middle ones, leaving two vials to the left and one to the right of the centered notches. Brandy-brown liquid sloshed in Parker's vial as she lifted it up in front of the light. Her pretty features squinting, she examined the small glass bottle with a surprising amount of intrigue and depth. Meanwhile, three other liquids of a similar shade and coloration sat undisturbed, still in the box.

"Looks like a whiskey." Parker pursed her lips a bit in concentration, "This some kind of... shot glass?"

"It's not really a glass if you can't put it down." Piper commented as she continued to examine the confines of the box, "And shouldn't there be... I don't know, more of it?"

"Check underneath the felt. It's probably a false bottom, rest of the liquor's in there." Parker said in a quick, almost prescriptive manner as she uncorked the vial and took a whiff—immediately regretting her decision, "Fuck, I think it's gone bad."

"You... know an awful lot about liquor boxes."

"I have hobbies."

Piper did as she was told and, sure enough, the part of the box that held the vials lifted right out. Underneath, the felt continued and insulated a rather large, spherical glass with a long thin bottleneck. It was big enough to touch the box's felt sides, and it had been there for so long that Piper struggled a bit to get it out. The decanter had a good weight to it, even held by the neck. But, curiously enough, instead of a crystal topper, it too had been corked. The same amber liquid sloshed inside the larger bottle as it did inside what Parker had (with surprising collegiate insight) declared to be a shot glass.

"What's this?" Piper put the bottle down gently on the couch and reached back into the box, "Some kind of... paper?"

"Distillery notes, probably." Parker braved another sniff, "People used to make their own alcohol, probably wanted to make more of it down the line."

Piper unfolded the piece of parchment—it felt like Bible paper, thin and delicate. The age of the document didn't help anything at all. Even unfolding it, Piper ripped it a little bit at the sides. Otherwise, it was in pretty good shape. The illustrations held up well enough, at least. But whether it was the age or just bad penmanship, she couldn't make heads or tails of whatever it actually said.

"Was I right?" Parker asked, clearly enjoying being good at this one thing, "Come on, was I right?"

"I can't tell." Piper said with some strain, "The handwriting is microscopic... and very angry."

"Gimme that." Parker snatched the parchment away from Piper, crinkling it horribly and ultimately coming to the same conclusion, "Fuck you're right."

"So... liquor?" Piper asked, gesturing to the disemboweled contents of their treasure chest, "That's what I got my junk cratered in for?"

"I mean... it's not a total loss." Parker held the uncorked glass up as if in a toast, "There are worse things that we could have found up there. Like racy pics of Bubby Judy. Remember that?"

"Ooh fuck don't remind me." Piper shivered at the long-repressed memory, "Okay, could be worse, so much worse."

Piper looked at the remaining three vials on the couch. Parker had been surprisingly good at convincing her that this was just a liquor box. Which, was, apparently a thing. The big bottle was the decanter, the little bottles were shot glasses, but why had they come pre-poured? And somehow the idea of old twentieth-century people lugging around a box that clocked in at a vagina-bustingly heavy weight just to keep their liquor and their pre-poured shot glasses safe didn't seem to jive well. So many questions about—

"Jesus Tapdancing Christ Parker, what are you doing?!" Piper shouted, stopping her sister mid-pour, "You can't drink that!"

"Okay, I almost dropped that, and I would have been so pissed." Parker pointed dangerously towards her little sister, "Why can't I drink this?"

"I-It's old!" Piper answered in bewilderment, "I-It's gross a-and it's not yours!"

"That has literally never stopped me from doing anything." Parker said with a flat face

"Oh God, Parker—"

"What, I'm kidding! Mostly." Parker raised her glass again, "Come on, we deserve it! We busted our asses cleaning out Mom's attic. We deserve a little bit more than pizza, right?"

"Fuck Parker, I don't know." Piper grimaced at the glass vials.

All of this gave her the creeps for some reason. As convincing as Parker's Liquor Box theory was, the idea of drinking strange liquids out of glasses that she didn't know rubbed Piper the wrong way. Everything checked out right, but something just made Piper's hair stand on end...

"Come on, I won't even tell Mom." Parker said in her rare, halfway-decent Big Sister voice, "We've got a new baby on the way, and we won't get to do this sisterly bonding thing a lot once we're up to our eyebrows in dirty diapers."

Parker raised her glass again, just a little higher

"Our little secret." Parker said with a smile that honestly made Piper believe she wasn't just doing this for the chance to daydrink, "Promise."
1132212.title: Not Exactly Box Wine

choices: Parker screaming her head off in the other room.
The bedframe snapping underneath her.
Her new stomach demanding to be filled!
11322121.content:
"Fuck it, I did get my crotch nearly caved in for this..."

"That's the spirit!" Parker said, pressing one of the "shot glasses" into Piper's hand. The younger sister raised it to the same height as her older sister, clinking the glasses together and downing the booze at the same time. Parker slammed her glass down first, shortly followed by Piper. The two stared at one another, the corners of their mouths curling before...

"BLEEEEEARGH!"

The box went 2-0 against Piper, claiming her big sister as a consolation prize as the two collapsed onto their hands and knees, dry heaving from that rather revolting beverage. Even Parker, a seasoned veteran of dealing with lousy and nauseating beverages, was reduced to a quivering wreck by the contents of the 'liquor'.

"Oh....huuurk....god..." Piper moaned. "It's like....liquid dumpster..."

"...full of wet dogs..." Parker moaned in response, face half-smooshed against the ratty carpet. "Fuck....I'm gonna hurl..."

Amazingly, the two managed to keep their lunch down despite rolling around on the carpet in agony for a good ten minutes until Piper managed to fight through it and escape to the fridge, returning with an extra soda for each to wash down...whatever the hell they just drank. Piper felt like she did when she came down from the attic after a grueling couple of hours working, and the soda might not have helped this time.

"God, I'm gonna taste that in my nightmares..." Parker said, sipping at her beverage. "I think it's still curdling my insides."

Piper nodded in agreement, running her hand over her poor tummy. It did feel like the old alcohol was sitting well down there. "I don't even think I'm getting a buzz..."

"Oh good, so that's not just me...ech..."

The sound of a car door slamming shut suddenly rang through the air, followed by the distinctive crunch of gravel underfoot. The Black sisters exchanged a look, then glanced down at the booze box, a booze box they probably weren't supposed to be helping themselves to. Calling on years of experience covering up their activities before Mom got home, the girls sprang into action; Parker quickly refilled the two vials they emptied as Piper gathered up the papers and debris to return to the box, snapping it shut when Parker was finished. The door handle rattled as Piper dashed to her bedroom, chucked the box under a pile of dirty clothes, then leapt the back of the couch to land in a casual position as Harper Black shoved the door open with her hip, carrying a pair of pizza boxes with a soda in a plastic bag hooked onto her arm.

"Hey girls!" Harper announced brightly at the sight of the two sisters relaxing together on the couch. "How did the attic cleaning go?"

"Perfectly fine," Piper said, coolly sipping on her drink as her heart pounded in her chest. "Everything's where it's supposed to be now."

Harper raised an eyebrow. "What an oddly specific way of phrasing that, Piper."

"Um..."

"Actually, mom, we need to talk," Parker interrupted, rescuing Piper as she took out one of the photo albums that the girls found upstairs. "Or should I say..." she continued, opening to a specific page like a police officer presenting damning evidence. "Miss Cheer Captain?"

"WHAT?" Piper shouted, unable to stop a grin from crossing her face.

"Oh god, you found those old things," Harper said, blushing but in a good-natured way. "I should have known better then to let you two sneaks into all of my things."

"I'm picturing you in the skirt and pom-poms!" Piper said, bursting into laughter. "Holy shit!"

"Yeah, I bet she dated the hunky football captain who became a superstar quarterback too!" Parker joked with an elbow to Piper's shoulder, but was distracted by her mother looking at the ceiling with a guilty smile on her face.

"You didn't...you fucking didn't...!"

"Daniel Fisher, Portland Privateers," Harper said simply.

The jaws of the Black sisters hit the floor. "OH. MY. GOD!"

The box of bad booze lay forgotten in Piper's room as the Black family settled down for the evening, enjoying the pizza as a reward for a job well done and listening to the crazy tales of Harper's high school days, the backstory to old knick-knacks and toys found in the attic. Relief from the Black sisters at getting away with their abortive attempt at boozing and a great first day at work for their Mother made for a very positive and wholesome evening, with many laughs shared and more then a few tears as well. For the first time since Piper's dear old dad bolted, there was a feeling that things might turn out okay after all.

"Oh gosh, it's late," Harper suddenly interrupted her own story to reveal. "I have to be up early as hell for the OB/GYN."

"TMI, mom," Parker sniped, sipping on what was left of her soda.

"Oh come on, she doesn't have anything you don't have, what's TMI about it?" Piper retorted.

"Dunno," Parker said, stifling a lawn. "Just...feeling really tired all of a sudden."

"Yeah...me too actually..." Piper yawned, feeling her eyelids getting heavy.

"Must be tired after all your hard work today!" Harper said proudly. "Enjoy the feeling, soon you'll have trouble falling asleep no matter how hard you work."

"Mooom..." Piper groaned as her mother leaned in and gave her a peck on the cheek.

"Go ahead and get some sleep, dear," Harper continued, trotting over to Parker to give her a peck as well, who was so tired she forgot to wince. "You have the basement to clean out tomorrow."

"Wh-what?"

"Kidding," Harper giggled. "Goodnight girls!"

The two sisters groaned. "Night, mom."

After a few minutes of collecting themselves, the Parker sisters managed to climb to their feet and trapse towards their bedrooms. Parker grunted something that could have been a goodnight as she turned into her bedroom, and Piper responded with a grunt of her own, stumbling into her room.

"So...tired..."

Tugging off her shredded jeans, something fluttered out of her pocket and landed in the corner where it wouldn't be spotted until morning. Shoving it into her pocket to evade her mother, Piper hadn't even noticed that the innocuous sheet stuck to one of the impossible to decipher parchments, with a message written in the same tiny writing but far clearer and somewhat legible even at this age.

My Dearest Abigail,

Thank you for your recent letter. I am pleased to hear that Uncle Martin's business ventures have finally borne fruit. The man may be stubborn, but I cannot fault him for his spirit. I hope you and your father continue to thrive.

My efforts to combat the white plague continue, naturally. My attempts to combat the wasting away of flesh with my formula are so far unsuccessful; the restorative effect does not seem to combat the vile disease, merely alleviateing the symptoms for a period of time. Still, it seems the local Duchess and her court took an interests in the effects when the patient does not suffer from consumption, and their funding has been enough to keep me solvent. With good fortune, I will perhaps be able to come overseas for a visit soon.

In the meantime, I'm sending you a sampling of the tincture for my colleague Dr. Tyler. I would send it myself, but the old fool never seems to have a consistent address. I would greatly appreciate it if you would leave this with him at your convenience, as his knowledge of biology might bear fruit. With any luck, when we next meet each other, the white plague will finally be vanquished and I can return home a hero. Until that time, I hope life treats you well, and that soon our family can be united once more.

Warmest Regards,
Mortimer Black

Piper, naturally, was far too tired to even notice this as she collapsed back-first on her unmade bed, falling asleep the instant her head touched the pillow.

Her stomach curdled angrily as the tincture went to work.

---

Piper would sleep like a baby all through the night until she was suddenly woken up by-
11322121.title: Bad Booze

choices: 1) The Incredible Expansion of Piper & Parker Black
2) Piper Black's Horrible Hunger
3) Things Get Weird
4) Free Choice
113221213.content:
Piper would sleep like a baby all through the night until she was suddenly woken up by the sound of her stomach, demanding to be fed.

And honestly, Piper wasn't entirely surprised. All throughout the night, she had been having the strangest dreams. Getting trapped on a dessert island where everything was edible, and having to eat her way to safety. Mainlining a Vegas act with talking slices of pizza, and then scarfing her way down the chorus line. Bouncing through the stars on edible clouds made of fluffternutter as she slowly cleared the skies over the Eastern seaboard. A lot of grease on her stomach usually gave Piper weird dreams, but admittedly she didn't usually wake up hungrier than she did when she went to sleep.

Especially after eating all that Pizza.

"Fuuuuck..."

Piper moaned as she slowly came to life, shaking the sleep from her shoulders and rising with some effort. Her back was sore and her muscles ached. Must have been from doing all that hard work yesterday. Her mom was right; she and Parker really wore themselves out cleaning out the attic. Her entire body felt heavy, and when she finally got to her feet, she felt like one of those baby horses taking their first step. Her legs felt like jell-o.

In fact, her whole body felt strange. Like something was wrong somehow. It was hard to put her finger on, but there was definitely a difference this morning. Looking in the full-body mirror tucked away in he corner of her messy room, Piper could see no evidence of anything like that. She was the same old Piper black—big tits, bedhead, and all. Although, standing at a certain angle...

"Fuuuuuck..."

Piper frowned at the small pooch on what she could have sworn to have been flat stomach. She'd put in her fat years as a kid. Now would be a really shitty time for her to have to start watching every piece of pizza that passed her lips. She was probably just bloated. Water weight, period, whatever, she told herself as she made slight adjustments to her posture in effort to hide the slight bulge of tum. It was way too early in the morning to start thinking up excuses as to why she had a little extra padding around her middle. Something smelled way too good.

"Oh fuck..."

And she was way too hungry.

Forgoing the habitual first-dibs bathroom hogging, Piper was further enticed to come into the kitchen by smell of sizzling bacon and cooked eggs hanging heavily in the house. Her naked feet touched linoleum as she took her first few steps inside.

"Ma?" Piper asked sleepily, "Whatcha cookin'?"

"It's nine 'o' clock, Pitstain, Ma's at work." Parker said in a bored, occupied tone of voice as she stood in front of the not-often-used Black Family oven, "Makin' breakfast, you want some?"

"Yeah, yeah, cool." Piper scooched a chair out from underneath the dinner table, "Wait, did you say nine?"

"Nine." Parker reiterated flatly, nibbling on a piece of bacon

"In the morning?"

"The one after eight, before ten."

"Last week you threatened to strangle me for waking you up at ten."

Parker piled two plates high with bacon and eggs and placed them on the serving dish that their mother had gotten four or five years ago at a yard sale. They'd almost never had a use for it until now, and it was just the right size for Parker's prodigious breakfast. Piper had honestly expected for Parker's one activity to have gotten her through the rest of the month, milking her part of cleaning the attic for all it was worth not to do anything. But here she was, making breakfast for the two of them! Despite her relative inability to do much of anything, she was surprisingly capable when it came to breakfast food—and only breakfast food. "Hangover food" was what she called it. And aside from the fact that she cooked her eggs runny, Piper had little reason to complain about it. Especially not this morning.

"Couldn't sleep." Parker said in a sort of not-all-there-yet way, piling her own plate high with food before relinquishing the breakfast spread to her little sister, "I had the weirdest dream about eating a giant marshmallow, and I was afraid that I was gonna wake up and my pillow would be gone."

"Same, actually." Piper commented as she readied her own cache of breakfast food, "Thanks for the Breakfast Bar."

"No sweat, I wasn't gonna eat it all anyway." the older Black said, hunkering over her food and taking hearty bites, "Jff... mmm... Just figured I'd be nice for once. Woke up feeling like my stomach had a hangover."

"Is that how you say you're hungry?" Piper reached across the table for the box of Pop-Tarts that had been sitting there since she got them from the cabinet two or three days ago, "Because that doesn't sound like you're hungry."

"Shut up twerp, I made you breakfast, I can say what I want." Parker grumbled, "Now hand me one of those..."

No sooner had the food hit the plate that it started going into Piper. She was starving like she hadn't been in years. Just how much of an appetite had she worked up after yesterday's attic cleaning exercise? The silverware clinked against the table, muffled by the paper plates, as Piper stabbed at bite after bite from her spread. She took open-mouthed chomps out of her toast, and ate entire mouthfuls of fluffy yellow eggs. Just how much had Parker been intending to eat if she'd made all of this?

And why did Piper have the weirdest craving for—

"Hey, I made you breakfast, get me the milk."

Piper bawked at her and her sister being on the same page for once. Piper hated milk. Everyone in the Black family hated milk. That was a cereal-only investment. But, after cramming a few more bites into her mouth, Piper obeyed and retrieved the gallon of whole milk from the fridge. And the biscuits she'd had left over from her trip to Dakota's—her mom made the best biscuits...

"Coffee." Parker commanded again, gruffly, "On the counter."

"What happened to drinking it—" Piper unholstered her finger guns and smiled absurdly, "—Parker Black"

"I swear to God I will fucking kill you."

Some things never changed. Despite the overall strangeness of this morning, at least Parker still wasn't a morning person. That would be weird. Waking up hungry was one thing, bloated was another, but for Parker to be a functioning human being without a cup of coffee or a little Hair of the Dog would have been Defcon 5 level weird. Once Piper handed the mug over, Parker poured enough milk into her coffee that it turned from a dark brown to a light khaki color. Then she ripped open five of the sugars they'd pocketed from the coffee shop last time they were there and dumped them into the mix. Piper had never been a big fan of coffee, but it looked good. Everything looked good. It was like Piper had a craving for just about everything she could see...

"You done with that?" Piper smacked her lips, her mouth feeling dry

"What? Yeah, go ahead."

Piper took the jug, unscrewed the cap, and tilted her head back. She took a few good gulps, feeling satisfied as her body got what it was craving. Taking a deeper breath, she leaned back again for longer as the cold milk washed down her throat.

"Gross—who drinks milk like that?" Parker scowled, "Better, who drinks just straight milk?"

"Shut up, I had a weird..." Piper struggled to find the word, "Craving."

"Whatever, mom."

Sitting back down, it felt almost entirely too fast before the rest of breakfast was over and done with. Piper managed to tuck away more for breakfast than she probably would have eaten before dinner on any other day. Working up an appetite was one thing, but Piper would admit to having pigged out a little. Her full stomach swelled a bit at the volume of her breakfast, taut and tight despite its convex shape.

"Guess I know where I got that gut from..." Piper thought inwardly as she pushed herself away from the dinner table, "Better cut back if I don't want to have to fight Ma for maternity pants..."

***


In the coming weeks, some of the strangeness would not go unnoticed. Piper and Parker, really their whole family, had always had healthy appetites—evidenced by their shared trait of large chests. However, that first morning was just a precursor to something else entirely.

Due to the character limitations in the Choices below, what could potentially happen in the coming weeks will be listed below.

1) Piper and Parker's appetites not only continue to grow out of hand, but so do their figures! In a relatively short amount of time, the Black sisters begin to balloon, finding themselves unable (or unwilling) to cease cleaning out every cubbard, pantry, and fridge they can get their hands on, while also unable to stop (or even stall!) their mysterious and worrying weight gain!

2) Piper manages to keep herself mostly contained, but at a cost. She needs food, and it's all she can think about. She's losing weight, at a slowed pace. But it isn't easy to keep herself in control when Parker is eating everything in sight, and finding every pound and thensome that Piper loses!

3) The mysterious vial may have been envisioned as a cure for tuberculosis, but it's side-effects include much more than an uncontrollable appetite and weight gain. Things are about to get weird.
113221213.title: Wakey Wakey, Eggs & Bakey

choices: whispered, "...a box of your finest donuts...please..."
demanded, "I want the family pack. The one for like...ten people."
shouted, "I WANT EVERYTHING ON YOUR FUCKING MENU!!!"
1132212132.content:
Piper Black was no pushover. She may not have had a bod that turned every head, but she was damned proud of how hard she worked to slim down since the days of Pudgey Piper and she would have cleaned out fifty attics before giving her trim figure up. Pushing her hunger to the back of her mind, Piper knuckled down and got to work, trimming down her belly fat and never once relenting on her schedule, jogging past countless sugary temptations and performing intense cardio to take her mind off of the calorie bomb "workout shakes" at the gym.

Checking herself in the bathroom mirror that morning, Piper examined her shrinking stomach, still looking for her abs behind that ever present layer of pudge. She could get away with hiding it underneath a dark colored shirt again, but it still persisted.

"Yeah, you keep going girl!" Piper told her reflection, barely restraining a whimper as she aimed finger-guns at herself in the mirror. "Staying trim and healthy! Light breakfast, then we meet Dakota for the morning jog!"

Piper felt pumped up and ready to go. Then she caught a whiff of breakfast and her confident look soured, her eyes resolving to a thousand-yard stare.

She was so hungry it wasn't even funny. And what's more, it didn't make sense. Sure you got hungry on diets, but Piper had done diets before. This was utter agony; she ate every light meal ravenously and yet it still felt like her stomach was eating away at her insides. It was so painful that Piper was afraid that one day she'd wake up and see a skeleton in the mirror. Like a literal skeleton.

"S-so...hungry....NO!"

Piper stamped her foot, her lower lip quivering. "Damn it Piper, you're better then this! You can do this! You can lose this belly fat, or I'll kick your flabby ass!" She aimed a kick at the bathroom counter and stubbed her big toe hard.

Swearing like a sailor, Piper hobbled into the kitchen to acquire what nourishment she could. Grabbing a banana out of the bowl sitting next to the stove, the younger Black sibling whimpered, her fingers trembling as though tempting her to grab just one more. It was fruit, you know? That's healthy. It's okay if you have two. Or more. Or the whole bowl. Maybe chase it up with those pop tarts you like, then a couple donuts, then---

"Aaaagh!" Piper shouted, peeling her banana and shoving it into her mouth like an animal. "Fuck!"

"Hey Pitstain, mom's napping!" Parker shouted from the living room. "Stuff it!"

"Why, you do plenty of stuffing on your own!" Piper retorted.

"Fuck -mmmmf- you!" Parker's swear was interrupted by her chewing.

Parker stomped towards the front door, right past her big sister occupying the sofa in the living room. And big sister was accurate; Piper's drive to diet wasn't something that her sister shared, and ever since the attic cleaning she had compounded on that inactivity, tending to stay home and playing video games instead of going out clubbing to get what little exercise she could.

As a result, Parker was starting to balloon. She was already far wider then before, dressed in stretchy shorts and a t-shirt that was a little too big for her a week ago and fit snugly today, riding up to expose an inch or two of pudgy round stomach. Her fluffy thighs forced her to take up a little more of the couch then before, and judging by how her boobs looked larger and sagged to the sides slightly, she had skipped wearing a bra today. Or perhaps just couldn't find one to fit.

"Seriously Pipes, mom's cranky today," Parker warned her, stuffing a danish taken from a big box lying next to her into her mouth, double chin wobbling as she spoke. "She came down and shouted at me when I dropped the frying pan earlier."

"Whatever,' Piper said bluntly, tugging on her light jacket.

"Uh, Piper?" Parker craned her neck to look past the TV at her sister directly. "You okay?"

"Of course I am!" Piper said. "Why wouldn't I be?"

"I dunno...you look like you're about to fall over." Parker picked up another danish, popping it daintily into her lips. It was blueberry lemon. Piper loved blueberry lemon. The younger sister betrayed a little whimper but quickly rebounded.

"I'm FINE, Parker! Seriously, stop freaking out." Piper kicked open the door roughly and backed out. "I'll be back after my jog."

"Whatever you s-" Parker began, but Piper slammed the door before she finished and took off at a jog. Every footstep jostled the tiny deposit of food in her stomach, reminder her how empty it actually felt. It almost started to hurt a little. It was agonizing, but it would be worth it. Classic Piper would be back in no time at all!

A few agonizing blocks later, Piper rendezvoused with Dakota at the corner, the cute little Texan already in her light jacket and jogging shorts and looking quite perky.

"Heya Pipes!" she said brightly. "Ready to get going?"

"Y-you know it!" Piper said, shakily giving her a thumbs up. Dakota paused, giving her a sideways look.

"You sure? You kind of look terrible today."

"Lousy breakfast," Piper admitted a little too quickly. "Not to worry though, I have a nice healthy lunch planned out. Mmm!" Piper's stomach roared and she whimpered again. Damn it, stop thinking about food!

"Okay then," Dakota said warily. "Let's get rolling then."

And they were off, bobbing through the streets of Daven's Port at jogging speed. Dakota kept a spirited pace, invigorated by the fall breeze and the fresh atmosphere of this brand new city. And Piper, stumbling along behind her, was in utter agony.

Breaking into a cold sweat that had nothing to do with her physical activity, every scent from every food joint she passed felt like a knife in her poor, poor stomach. It cried out for nourishment, for sustenance, for just a morsel of energy. She needed it, more then she ever needed anything in her life. Her ragged painful gasps of breath echoed with her footsteps until Piper stumbled to a stop, her eyes bloodshot and every inch of her trembling.

"Pipes?" Dakota called some distance away. "You okay?"

You can do this, Piper told herself. You can fight this. She straightened herself out, took a breath of fresh air...

...and breathed in the scent of Dee's Donuts. Her favorite donut store.

Piper stood like a statue, her eye twitching as Dakota ran up.

"Piper?" Dakota repeated, waving a hand in front of her face. "Is something wr-"

"YEAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAGH I CAN'T FUCKING TAKE IT ANYMORE!!!"

Piper's shriek launched Dakota backwards, landing roughly on the bus bench as Piper bolted into the donut store. She didn't care that every eye was on her, or how crazy or deranged she looked. None of that mattered. The only thing that mattered was the insatiable hunger inside of her. She needed to fill her stomach, and she needed to fill it NOW!"

Dee herself was behind the counter when Piper stormed inside. "Uh, Piper? How can I-" she began, then yelped as Piper physically leapt over the counter, grabbing Dee by the collar and staring into her soul. Dee capitulated under such a terrifying, manic look in her eyes.

"P-piper? Wh-what do you want?"

Piper licked her lips, a manic, deranged look in her eyes, and
1132212132.title: Piper Black's Horrible Hunger

choices: Piper's gnawing constant hunger only gets worse—and harder to control!
These hunger spells are hard but infrequent—they pop up at the worst times!
Free Choice
11322121322.content:
"I want the family pack." Piper finally demanded, "The one for like... then people."

"O-Okay, just..."

Piper took the hint and relinquished her grip on the proprietor's collar, leaving the pretty pink pinstriped blouse a little ruffled. The older woman took a cautionary step back and silently urged Piper to the correct side of the counter. Shambling back into the eatery proper, Piper moseyed towards a booth. But as the aroma of donuts began to overwhelm her sense of shame and the little voice in her head that told her to wait, she found herself at odds once again.

Clutching at her stomach, hunched over and a rumbling groan roaring from deep within her, Piper shut her eyes tight as the ringing in her ears returned. The donut shop started to fade around her, her vision narrowing into a red-rimmed tunnel as she felt her heartbeat behind her eardrums.

"Piper?" the owner asked with a touch of her shoulder, "Honey, are you o—"

"I'm fine." Piper snapped, "Just hurry up with those donuts, will you?!"

"You've got to pay first, hun." Dee sounded more concerned than offended at Piper's tone, "Cash or card?"

Piper reached into her bra and pulled out a clammy fifty dollar bill that was supposed to last her all week. She handed it over to the older woman and got back a nice crisp pair of ones and a couple of coins. She crumpled them up in one hand and shoved them in the pockets of her jogging shorts. Stumbling back over to the booth, she collapsed into her seat and sat with her head hung low in her hands.

What was wrong with her today? Everything she'd felt ever since she'd cleaned out the attic was finally coming to a head. She was irritable, grumpy, and more over, she was hungry. Dieting had never been this hard before. All she wanted to do was lose a little belly for God's sake! It wasn't like she was Porky Piper, somehow managing to shed almost a hundred and fifty pounds through puberty and running around the Port. How fair was it that now, when it was fifteen pounds tops, it should be so hard?

She would give anything for something to eat. Anything to make her stomach stop aching. She'd gone and blew all fifty of her bucks on some stupid amount of donuts and for what? There was no way she was going to eat all of these—

"Here you are hun." Dee said in a much warmer sort of voice, "You need some help getting these home?"

Piper's blood ran cold at the sight of the seven boxes stacked high on the table. The Ten People Party Palooza was a fixed set of donuts that couldn't be substituted. She'd gotten one for Dakota during her welcoming party. Back then it had taken her, Dakota, Zack, Madi, and Max to even make a dent in that thing. They'd all gone home with more donuts than they could handle and it took a whole three weeks for the Black family's portion, at least, to disappear. That hadn't been all that long ago, and Piper could have sworn she'd never eat donuts again. But now...

but now...

"What?" Piper asked finally, half-looking up at the manager

"I asked if you needed help getting these home?" Dee repeated, "I know your mama will appreciate you bringing these home. Good lord, she must be four months along now, right?"

"They're not for ma." Piper rasped, her mouth sandy and her throat dry, "They're for here."

"I'm sorry, hun, I didn't hear you, it sounded like—"

"I SAID THEY'RE FOR HERE." Piper hollered and slammed her open palms on the table, "Thank you, Dee, I think I can take it from here!"

Shaking her head, the manager did her best to put Piper's strange behavior out of her mind. Meanwhile, the poor girl had been left licking her lips as she began to rip into the boxes of donuts. Every flavor she could imagine was in there—starting with apple cinnamon. She practically forced the first donut into her mouth; amber colored filling oozed out from the sides and dolloped onto her cheeks and plopped on her boob. The taste was exquisite. Divine even. Piper had never tasted a goddamn donut so good in her entire life.

She needed more.

Three donuts went down without a hitch, all in four bites or less. She opened her mouth as wide as it could possibly go and forced the flaky pastries inside. She nearly choked a few times in thanks to the brown sugar powder. A quick run to the soda jerk for a free water fixed her issue and gave her enough time to move onto the boston creme.

Piper was an animal. She felt like she hadn't eaten anything in days. Weeks. Months. Ever. But the more Piper ate, the more her stomach seemed to feel empty. Bit by bit, she slowly filled her gullet with sugary snacks. But even as her first dozen fell by the wayside, all Piper could think about was more, More, MORE...

***


"Jesus Christ."

Dakota had spent her morning trying to track down her friend. Piper had shot off on her own in the middle of their jog, leaving her standing there worried out of her mind. She walked all around DP and had been calling her like crazy. Texting, messaging, she'd even tried Snapchat to check her location.

It wasn't until Hurley said Yanira had seen her in D's Donuts during a munchie run that she got a clue as to where she was. And that had been hours ago, there was no way she was still there!

But sure enough, there was Piper Black. Stuffed to the gills with a cemetery of discarded donut boxes around her. She'd been leaning back in her seat, a rounded stomach doming out from underneath her always impressive bust. She had a dazed, stupid look on her face. Almost like she was asleep. A low moan sounded from her booth—whether it was one of agony or enjoyment, Dakota had no idea.

She knew Piper was having a hard time with her diet, but this was a little extreme.

"Piper?" Dakota asked

"Dee..." the glutted gal said weakly, "Heeeey..."

She tried to move. God that looked painful. Her stomach was hard as a rock, and she looked more far along than her mom was. Leaning forward was out of the question for poor Piper. There was no give in that belly! Dakota hurried to her side and grabbed her by the arm.

"You flaked on our jog to go get donuts?" Dakota sounded more hurt than anything, "Jeez how many of these did you eat?"

"Dunno." Piper burped, "I just got... so hungry..."

The Texan clicked her tongue in mild concern for her friend. She'd been acting so weird lately, but this was strange even for her. She definitely didn't have the money to be buying expensive donuts like this willy-nilly. Piper was normally all about exploring the town, and she'd been super into their jogs! Whatever was going on with her friend must have been pretty important...

"Everything okay at home, P?"

"Why—ooogh—does everyone keep asking that?" Piper whined, touching the sides of her kicking food baby, "Fuck, I just... got hungry, okay?"

"Okay, okay." Dakota eased her friend to her feet, "You, uh... wanna finish our jog?"

"Noooo..." Piper whined, leaning belly-first towards the floor, "Take me home..."

Piper had no idea what had come over her. The impossible pile of donuts had seemingly met its fate at her hands. And her hands alone! That had to have been at least fifty donuts, all by her lonesome. That was incredible. It was impossible! And it certainly wasn't going to help her work off that starter belly she'd been sporting.

Tomorrow would be another day. Another chance to get this diet thing right.

But tonight, maybe, she should get some rest...
11322121322.title: Piper's Ten-People Party Pack

choices: "Is it weird that I'm kinda curious what that stuff is like?"
"We should tell your sister what happened."
"What did your mom have this stuff for anyway?"
113221213223.content:
This had to be what hell was like.

As the week came to a close, Piper didn't have a repeat encounter of the party pack incident, but God she came pretty damn close. Dakota, being the awesome friend that she was, kept a close eye on her, making sure she didn't inadvertently jog into a greasy spoon to order a delectable cheeseburger or stray from her usual lunch options of salads and soups, but it just made things worse. Her stomach screamed, wailed for nourishment when she gave it so much as a passing thought. It was enough to make her question whether or not something was seriously wrong with her, not just because she was NEVER this desperately hungry from dieting before, but because it didn't seem to be working. At all.

That belly of hers remained steadfast, and the day after the donut incident was even joined by a slight layer of pudge on her hips that made her jogging pants tight and uncomfortable. Mentally exhausted by the gnawing hunger, Piper didn't even have the energy to mention her inexplicable sizing up to anyone, and if Dakota or her family noticed they kept polite about it. It may not even have been real, just her wild, hungry imagination at work, since thinking about putting on pounds was the next logical step to having your every waking thought dominated by this torturous, gnawing hunger.

Still she suffered through it all, oftentimes reduced to tears out of sheer frustration, but she held. And after a agonizing night where she declined a second helping of her mom's famously awesome meatloaf, she collapsed into her bed, weak and destitute, hoping this was a night she wouldn't spend dreaming of food.

---

"Heeeey Piper? You up yet?"

Piper groaned, sluggishly sitting up in bed as her rat's nest hair fell into her eyes.

"What?" she mumbled almost incoherently at her sister peeking her head through the door.

"Well when you have a minute, gotta ask you something," Parker said snootily, vanishing behind the doorframe. Piper growled as she spun her legs out of bed, getting shakily to her feet and stretching out her back. Stumbling to the bathroom, she scratched herself in a way that would get her a scolding from her mother as she braced herself for another day of ceaseless unrelenting hunger. Though, now that she thought about it, it wasn't that bad today. Almost felt like normal. Grateful for this small relief from the agony of the last week, Piper crossed the threshold and turned on the light of the bathroom, grabbing her toothbrush and applying a liberal helping of toothpaste before-

The toothbrush clattered into the sink as Piper stared openly at her reflection. Her...her belly. The one she spent so long agonizingly trying to lose.

It was gone!

She ran a hand over her abs to be sure, feeling the usual flat surface she came to know and love. Her heart felt like singing. At last, the dieting worked! Skinny Piper was back, baby! And...surprisingly fast too.

Quickly getting dressed, and reveling in the ease of tugging her pants, Piper dashed out of her room and nearly slammed into Parker on the way out.

"Gah! Watch it, tubby!" Piper snapped.

"That doesn't even make sense, pitstain!" Parker sniped back.

"Whatever," Piper grumbled, her mood somewhat spoiled by her sister's bitchiness. "What do you...uh..." The younger sister openly stared again, not sure what she was looking at.

"Well, if you're done being an ass, did you sort the laundry last night? I think you gave me mom's maternity stuff by mistake, these shorts are HUGE on me." She gestured towards the large shorts she held onto her skinny frame with both hands.

Parker was wrong and right. Those shorts were definitely the cute ones that Parker picked up after she burst her jeans open after a second helping of dinner the other night, and what's more...they were way too big on her. Piper wasn't braindead, right? Her sister had spent the whole last week porking up like crazy, and now...she was back to normal? What the fuck happened?

"I didn't sort any laundry," Piper said dismissively, the cogs in her mind turning, unceremoniously shoving past her. "I think I'm losing my shit," she mumbled to herself.

"What? Piper, wait!"

---

The younger Black sibling paced back and forth at the street corner, her mind trying to process the impossible things she saw, when the voice she was waiting for chimed in.

"Hey, Piper!" Dakota called out, in the same tone as one would use with a sick friend you needed to help out. "Ready to get going? We can take it easy if you need to, once around the-yeaah!" Dakota yelped as Piper grabbed her by the arm and led her back to the house a few doors down. "Okay, I'm s-sorry about making you jog, I'm just-"

"I need a second pair of eyes, to make sure I'm not going insane," Piper announced unceremoniously. "C'mere."

The pair of them stumbled up to the Black residence again, Piper kicking open the door as she strolled right in.

"Oh my god would you fucking stop it?" Parker snapped, standing in the living room, a modest bagel clutched in her hand and her jacket around her other arm. "If you break the door again mom's going to kill you."

"Sorry, I needed to show Dakota something," Piper explained, looking over at her friend's shocked expression on seeing the incredible change to the piggy Parker's figure.

"Whatever. I'm going out, I'll be back at lunchtime." Shoving past the two friends, Parker departed for her day trip, slamming the door behind her and leaving a stunned duo in the dust.

"She...she got skinny fast," Dakota said stupidly.

"Me too, and it happened overnight," Piper explained, lifting up her shirt to demonstrate. "So I'm not going insane, this really happened?"

"No, I see it too, definitely." Dakota looked shell-shocked at the impossible transformations taking place in front of her. "I...what the hell happened? How did you and Parker lose weight so quickly? How come you don't look like you want to gnaw your own face off anymore?"

Piper winced. "Was it really that bad?"

"Well, kinda," Dakota admitted. "Last night you looked like you could clean out Polyburger's whole stock."

"I felt like I could, this whole week I couldn't stop thinking about eating," Piper ranted. "It was insatiable, I remember just waking up feeling so hungry. I almost cleaned out the leftover pizza from the other night but-"

Something finally clicked into place. Dakota looked on in confusion as Piper put it all together. The gnawing hunger, the pizza, a reward for cleaning out the attic, where they found...

"THE WINE BOX!"

"What?" Dakota asked, but Piper was already gone, having sped into her room. Tenatively following, Dakota peered around the corner and was hit in the face with a dirty bra carelessly flung behind Piper as she dug through the dirty pile of laundry, finally revealing a familiar wooden crate. With a look of triumph, Piper picked up the box and showed it to Dakota like a prized hunting trophy, opening it up to show off the tincture and the glass vials inside.

"It's this stuff!" Piper exclaimed. "Me and Parker were in the attic and found this thing, she said it was a old timey wine box so we tried it out!"

Dakota raised an eyebrow. "You found an old box full of a weird liquid and you decided to drink it?"

"It was HER idea!" Piper scowled in the direction that Parker had gone. "And it tasted like carpet cleaner, I bet it messed up my system or something, probably screwed with my sister too!"

"But why would it cause you to suddenly lose weight?"

Piper's triumphant smile faltered, unable to explain this little snag.

"What kind of alcohol even is this?" Dakota questioned, pulling out her phone. "Maybe Zack knows, his parents are wine collectors and...eh?"

Dakota looked down, realizing she stepped on something when she idly shifted her feet. Reaching down, she picked up an aging piece of parchment.

"My dearest Abigail," Dakota recited. "Is this some sort of school project?"

"No, it must have come from the box," Piper said, looking at the similarly aged looking papers tucked into the sides of the tincture case. "What's it say?" Dakota scanned through the letter at a quick pace.

"'Uncle Martin'...'duchess'...yada yada...'white plague'...'My attempts to combat the wasting away'..."

Dakota looked up from the parchment, her expression a mix of shock and amusement.

"Piper," she explained. "I...think you two drank medicine."

"What? Gimme that!" Piper said, snatching the paper and scanning through it, her expression softening. "Fuck me, you're right, it's medicine, some sort of cure for a white plague. What the hell's a white plague?"

"Tuberculosis," Dakota pointed out. "And it doesn't seem to have worked anyway. Though that duchess character seems to have liked it for some other reason."

"Maybe she just liked eating?" Piper suggested. "I know I couldn't stop thinking about it when that stuff was in me."

"Yeah, I remember you ate like fifty donuts and now look at you, skinny as ever."

"You sound jealous."

The two girls laughed, trailing off as they looked at the tincture set, still plenty full of that weird old-timey medicine. As Piper looked at the stuff with mixed feelings at the idea of such a strange thing actually existing, Dakota spoke up to break the silence.
